revision.comment: Bot: Change redirected category [[:Category:French writers' organisations|French writers' organisations]] to [[:Category:French writers' organizations|French writers' organizations]]
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=August 2013}} {{French literature sidebar}} The '''Société littéraire des Goncourt''' ('''Goncourt Literary Society'''), usually called the '''académie Goncourt''' ('''Goncourt Academy'''), is a French literary organization based in Paris. It was founded <!-- in 1900 (citation?) --> by the French writer and publisher [[Edmond de Goncourt]] (1822–1896). He wanted to create a new way to encourage literature in France, and disagreed with the contemporary policies of the [[Académie française]].
==Formation and organization== Wishing to honor his deceased brother [[Jules de Goncourt|Jules]] (1830–1870), Goncourt bequeathed his estate to establish an organization to promote [[French literature|literature in France]]. He named his friend, the writer [[Alphonse Daudet]], along with [[Léon Hennique]], to oversee and administer his estate. The society was to consist of ten members, of whom eight were nominated in the will. Each of the members was to receive an annuity of 6,000 [[French franc|francs]], and a yearly prize of 5,000 francs was to be awarded to the author of some work of fiction. After some litigation, the academy was constituted in 1903.<ref>{{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Goncourt, De|volume=7|page=231}}</ref> Since then, each December, a ten-member board of the Académie has awarded the ''[[Prix Goncourt]]'' for the best work of [[fiction]] of the year.
Membership is reserved to writers who have produced works in the French language, but it is not limited to citizens of France. In 1996, the [[Spain|Spanish]] novelist and scriptwriter [[Jorge Semprún]] was elected as the first foreigner to become a member of the academy.
In addition to the Prix Goncourt, which comes with a symbolic cheque of 10 euros, the Académie Goncourt awards honors for first novel and achievements in short story, poetry and biography genres.
The ten members of the academy are usually called ''les Dix'' (the Ten). They meet the first Tuesday of each month, except in summer. Since 1914, they have convened in an oval room, the ''salon Goncourt'', on the second floor of the Restaurant Drouant,<ref>[http://www.drouant.com/fr/lhistoire/0-5-1-1.html "Histoire"], Restaurant Drouant. Note: The restaurant Drouant was founded as a ''bar tabac'' by the [[Alsace|Alsatian]] Charles Drouant, who expanded it to a [[bistrot]]. It made its reputation from the fresh oysters delivered by Drouant's brother, who farmed them. Daudet was a regular, as were artists such as [[Renoir]], [[Auguste Rodin|Rodin]] and [[Camille Pissarro]].</ref> place Gaillon, in the [[2nd arrondissement of Paris|heart of Paris]]. The [[cutlery]] which they use while dining there constitutes the main physical continuity of the academy. Each new member receives the fork and knife of the member whom he (or she) is replacing, and the member's name is engraved on the knife and the fork.
==Current members== [[File:Les Académiciens Goncourt (9820285024).jpg|thumb| Members of the Académie Goncourt in 2013. From left to right: Philippe Claudel, Tahar Ben Jelloun, Didier Decoin, Paule Constant, Patrick Rambaud, Bernard Pivot.]] * [[Éric-Emmanuel Schmitt]], elected 2016 * [[Didier Decoin]], elected 1995; currently Secretary-General * [[Françoise Chandernagor]], elected 1995 * [[Bernard Pivot]], elected 2004; President since 2014 * [[Tahar Ben Jelloun]], elected 2006 * [[Patrick Rambaud]], elected 2008 * [[Virginie Despentes]], elected 2016 * [[Pierre Assouline]], elected 2012 * [[Philippe Claudel]], elected 2012 * [[Paule Constant]], elected 2013
==Academicians by seat== {{div col|colwidth=30em}}
===1st Seat=== * 1900–1942 : [[Léon Daudet]] * 1942–1944 : [[Jean de La Varende]] * 1944–1954 : [[Colette]] * 1954–1970 : [[Jean Giono]] * 1971–1977 : [[Bernard Clavel]] * 1977–2004 : [[André Stil]] * since 2004 : [[Bernard Pivot]]
===2nd Seat=== * 1900–1907 : [[Joris-Karl Huysmans]] * 1907–1910 : [[Jules Renard]] * 1910–1917 : [[Judith Gautier]] * 1918–1924 : [[Henry Céard]] * 1924–1939 : [[Pol Neveux]] * 1939–1948 : [[Sacha Guitry]] * 1949–1983 : [[Armand Salacrou]] * 1983–2016 : [[Edmonde Charles-Roux]] * since 2016 : [[Éric-Emmanuel Schmitt]]
===3rd Seat=== * 1900–1917 : [[Octave Mirbeau]] * 1917–1947 : [[Jean Ajalbert]] * 1947–1973 : [[Alexandre Arnoux]] * 1973–1995 : [[Jean Cayrol]] * since 1995 : [[Didier Decoin]]
===4th Seat=== * 1900–1940 : [[J.-H. Rosny aîné]] * 1940–1942 : [[Pierre Champion]] * 1943–1971 : [[André Billy]] * 1971–2012 : [[Robert Sabatier]] * since 2013 : [[Paule Constant]]
===5th Seat=== * 1900–1948 : [[J.-H. Rosny jeune]] * 1948–1967 : [[Gérard Bauër]] * 1967–1968 : [[Louis Aragon]] * 1969–1983 : [[Armand Lanoux]] * 1983–2008 : [[Daniel Boulanger]] * since 2008 : [[Patrick Rambaud]]
===6th Seat=== * 1900–1935 : [[Léon Hennique]] * 1936–1950 : [[Léo Larguier]] * 1951–1977 : [[Raymond Queneau]] * 1977–2008 : [[François Nourissier]] * since 2006: [[Tahar Ben Jelloun]]
===7th Seat=== * 1900–1918 : [[Paul Margueritte]] * 1919–1923 : [[Émile Bergerat]] * 1924–1937 : [[Raoul Ponchon]] * 1938–1948 : [[René Benjamin]] * 1949–1971 : [[Philippe Hériat]] * 1972–2011 : [[Michel Tournier]] * 2011–2015 : [[Régis Debray]] * since 2016 : [[Virginie Despentes]]
===8th Seat=== * 1900–1926 : [[Gustave Geffroy]] * 1926–1929 : [[Georges Courteline]] * 1929–1973 : [[Roland Dorgelès]] * 1973–1995 : [[Emmanuel Roblès]] * since 1995 : [[Françoise Chandernagor]]
===9th Seat=== * 1900–1925 : [[Élémir Bourges]] * 1926–1937 : [[Gaston Chérau]] * 1937–1958 : [[Francis Carco]] * 1958–1996 : [[Hervé Bazin]] * 1996–2011 : [[Jorge Semprún]] * since 2012 : [[Philippe Claudel]]
===10th Seat=== * 1900–1949 : [[Lucien Descaves]] * 1950–1970 : [[Pierre Mac Orlan]] * 1970–2011 : [[Françoise Mallet-Joris]] * since 2012 : [[Pierre Assouline]] {{div col end}}
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Academie Goncourt}} [[Category:French writers' organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1900]] [[Category:1900 establishments in France]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1903]]

revision.comment: /* External links */ [[Category:Recipients of the Pour le Mérite (military class)]]
revision.text:
{{hatnote|Not to be confused with [[Alexander Dmitriev-Mamonov]] (1758-1803), Catherine the Great's paramour.}} [[File:Orest_Kiprensky_035.jpg|thumb|200px|Alexander Dmitriev-Mamonov; portrait by [[Orest Kiprensky]].]] '''Alexander Ivanovich Dmitriev-Mamonov''' (Russian: Александр Иванович Дмитриев-Мамонов; 24 December 1787 in [[Saint Petersburg]] – 9 December 1836 in [[Moscow]]) was the commander of a Belarusian [[Hussar]] regiment and a [[battle painter]].
== Biography == He was born into a noble family and was the son of Major-General Ivan Dmitriev-Mamonov (1754-1812). His mother, Mariya (1768-1794), died when he was only seven and his father remarried into the Tolstoy family.<ref>[https://www.geni.com/people/%D0%98%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD-%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87-%D0%94%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2-%D0%9C%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2/6000000008806275819 Ivan Dmitriev-Mamonov] @ [[Geni.com]].</ref> Most sources say that his father's second wife, Yelena (1772-1855), was his mother.
After 1806, he served as an [[actuary]] at the [[Collegium of Foreign Affairs]], then moved to the State Chancellery.<ref name="N">[http://napoleonic.ru/история/персоналии/дмитриев-мамонов-александр-иванович Brief biography] @ Napoleonic.ru.</ref>
In 1812, he joined the [[Narodnoe Opolcheniye|People's Militia]] in Moscow. He received the rank of Lieutenant and served in the battles of [[Battle of Ostrovno|Ostrovno]], [[Battle of Valutino|Valutino]], [[Battle of Borodino|Borodino]] and [[Battle of Krasnoi|Krasnoi]]. In 1813, he was assigned to a Hussar regiment, commanded by General [[Pyotr Petrovich Palen|Pyotr Palen]], that followed Napoleon's retreating army and participated in numerous battles before reaching Paris.<ref name="N" /> [[File:A.I.Dmitriev-Mamonov-Fere-Champenoise.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The [[Battle of Fère-Champenoise]]]] In 1816, he became an [[adjutant]] to General [[Nikita Volkonsky]] and promotions followed rapidly. By 1823, he had been promoted to Colonel and left the General's service.<ref name="N" /> He had several friends among the [[Decembrist revolt|Decembrists]] and the courage to speak out on behalf of those who had been exiled or placed in custody. In 1827, he was given command of a Hussar regiment and, in 1830, took part in suppressing the [[November Uprising]]. The following year, he was promoted to Major-General.<ref name="N" /> Over the next few years, he commanded [[light cavalry]] and [[Uhlan]] regiments, as well as the Hussars.
In addition to his military activities, he was an amateur artist and brought back numerous sketches from the battles he had seen during the Napoleonic campaigns. In 1820, he was one of the founders of the [[Imperial Society for the Encouragement of the Arts]], together with {{ill|Ivan Alexeyevich Gagarin|ru|Гагарин, Иван Алексеевич}} and [[Pyotr Kikin]]. Seven years later, he established a drawing school. Many of his sketches and watercolors are displayed in the buildings at [[Tsarskoye Selo]].
In 1835, he moved into the civil service and became a [[State Counsellor (Russia)|State Councillor]] at the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The awards he received during his military career include the [[Order of Saint Vladimir]], [[Order of Saint Anna]], the [[Medal "For the Capture of Paris"]] and the order [[Pour le Mérite]].<ref name="N" />
His wife, Sofia, was [[Maid of honour|maid of honor]] to [[Maria Feodorovna (Sophie Dorothea of Württemberg)|Maria Feodorovna]]. His son, [[Emmanuil Dmitriev-Mamonov|Emmanuil]], was a portrait painter, art historian and noted [[Slavophile]].
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{commonscat inline|House of Dmitriev-Mamonov}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dmitriev-Mamonov, Alexander}}

revision.comment: +[[Category:Operas based on real people]].
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=December 2016}}{{no footnotes|date=December 2016}}}} {{Infobox opera | name = Ali Pascha von Janina | type = [[Singspiel]] | composer = [[Albert Lortzing]] | image = Albert Lortzing.jpg | image_upright = 0.8 | caption = The composer | translated_name = | librettist = Lortzing | language = German | based_on = | premiere_date = {{Start date|1828|02|01|df=y}} | premiere_location = [[Städtische Bühnen Münster]] }} '''''Ali Pascha von Janina oder Die Franzosen in Albanien''''' (''Ali Pasha of Ioannina or The French in Albania'') is a one-act German [[singspiel]]. It is set around 1820 in [[Ioannina]], then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]] and is named after its central character [[Ali Pasha of Ioannina]].
Its music and [[libretto]] are both by the German composer [[Albert Lortzing]] – it can be considered as a precursor to his later full-length operas. He had decided to write for the stage in 1823, aged 22. [[Orientalism|Orientalist]] subjects were then popular and so he chose that theme for his first work. On 30 January 1824 he married [[Rosina Regina Ahles]] and soon afterwards he completed the music, but it took him until 1828 to find a theatre which would mount the work.
The couple took on an engagement at the [[Landestheater Detmold|Hoftheater Detmold]] in autumn 1826, as well as appearing in theatres in [[Münster]] and [[Osnabrück]]. Lortzing finally premiered the work in the [[Städtische Bühnen Münster]] in on 1 February 1828, where it was a moderate success and enabled him to continue writing plays.
==Characters== *Ali Bey, Pasha of Joannina ([[bass (voice type)|bass]]) *Ibrahim, overseer of the pasha's harem (bass) *Captain Bernier ([[tenor]]) *Lieutenant Robert, Bernier's friend (tenor) *Arianna, a girl from Corfu ([[soprano]]) *Soldiers, sailors, guards, slavegirls, slaves, imprisoned maidens (chorus)
==Plot== Stationed in Ioannina with his battalion, the French naval captain Bernier has fallen in love with Arianna, a beautiful girl from the nearby island of [[Corfu]]. However, he has not heard from her for days and is worried about what might have happened to her. Bernier's friend Robert tries in vain to comfort him.
Bernier's concerns prove justified – Arianna had been captured by a wild horde whilst out walking on the beach and taken to Ali Pasha's [[harem]]. Ali Pasha cannot bear her laments and complaints and orders her to forget Bernier since she now belongs to him alone. The other women in the harem are unwilling to raise Arianna's hopes and instead advise her that the only way to survive her suffering is to submit herself to fate and Ali Pasha's will.
In the meantime Bernier receives news of his beloved and gains entry to Ali Pasha's palace under a pretext. Ali Pasha is initially delighted to welcome a Frenchman and brings in Arianna to show her off to him, make Bernier envious and draw on Bernier's knowledge of women.
Bernier and Arianna find it hard to conceal their true feelings and pretend that they do not know each other, but only a few minutes after Ali Pasha leaves she admits to her love. Ali Pasha overhears this from a hiding place and rushes back in swearing vengeance. Bernier is chained up but Robert and the French battalion succeed in penetrating the harem. They free Bernier and Arianna and return with them to France.
==External links== *http://www.operone.de/opern/alipasch.html *http://d-nb.info/gnd/300222602
{{Albert Lortzing}} {{authority control}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 4 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Alliance of Women Directors | image = File:Alliance of Women Directors (logo).gif | image_size = 250px | alt = Alliance of Women Directors Logo | abbreviation = AWD | motto = ''Vision Focus Action!'' | formation = {{start date|1997}} | type = 501(c)(3) | purpose = Education, support and advocacy for women directors in the entertainment industry | leader_title = Co-Chair | leader_name = Eleonore Dailly | leader_title2 = Co-Chair | leader_name2 = Jennifer Warren | board_of_directors = Jacqui Barcos, Sarah Bullion, Marty Elcan, Rachel Goldberg, Hilari Scarl, Michelle Steffes | website = http://www.allianceofwomendirectors.org }} The '''Alliance of Women Directors (AWD)''' is an American [[501(c) organization#501.28c.29.283.29|501c(3)]] [[nonprofit organization]] created to support education and advocacy for women [[Film director|directors]] in film, television, and new media.<ref name=Variety2009>{{cite journal | last=Friend|first=David|url=https://variety.com/2009/film/news/women-directors-eye-oscar-1118011839/|title=Women directors eye Oscar|journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=November 29, 2009|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref><ref name=AWDAbout>{{cite web|title=Alliance of Women Directors About Page|url=http://www.allianceofwomendirectors.org/#!page2/cjg9|publisher=Alliance of Women Directors|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref> The AWD, established in 1997, has over 150 members<ref name=AWDmembers/> and is based in Los Angeles.<ref name=AWDAbout/>
==Programs== The AWD works to support and promote the work, visibility, and professional development for female directors<ref name=sdsu>{{cite web|url=http://womenintvfilm.sdsu.edu/resources.html|title=Resources: Organizations Concerned with Women in Television and Film On-Line|publisher=Center for the Study of Women in Television and Film, San Diego State University|access-date=April 3, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328164210/http://womenintvfilm.sdsu.edu/resources.html|archive-date=2015-03-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> through a variety of programs including screenings,<ref name=BehindCamera>{{cite web|url=http://www.womenbehindthecamera.com/festivals.html|title=Festivals & Screenings|website=Women Behind the Camera|access-date=March 22, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Runoff>{{cite web|url=http://filmguide.lafilmfest.com/tixSYS/2014/xslguide/eventnote.php?EventNumber=5044|title=Runoff|website=[[LA Film Festival]]|publisher=Film Independent|access-date=March 22, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402141437/http://filmguide.lafilmfest.com/tixSYS/2014/xslguide/eventnote.php?EventNumber=5044|archive-date=2015-04-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> educational events,<ref name=City>{{cite web|url=http://www.citypulse.io/event/1944068/film-media-entertainment/general-assembly/new-models-of-distribution-panel/07-oct-14|title=New Models of Distribution Panel|website=City Pulse|access-date=April 3, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402135052/http://www.citypulse.io/event/1944068/film-media-entertainment/general-assembly/new-models-of-distribution-panel/07-oct-14|archive-date=2015-04-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=Stevens>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmspecific.com/public/610.cfm |title=Alliance of Women Directors Film Festival & Distribution Seminar|website=Film Specific| access-date=March 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Bollinger|first1=Lee|last2=O'Neill|first2=Carole|date=2008|title=Women in Media Careers: Success Despite the Odds|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y71-YCYv-48C|location=Lanham, Maryland|publisher=[[University Press of America]]|page=|isbn=978-0-761-84133-3|access-date=March 20, 2015}}</ref> and industry parties<ref name=womenand>{{cite web|url=http://womenandhollywood.com/2009/01/23/sundance-dispatch-a-celebration-of-women-filmmakers/|title=Sundance Dispatch: A Celebration of Women Filmmakers|last=Burton|first=Maria|website=Women and Hollywood|date=January 23, 2009|access-date=April 3, 2015}}</ref> both for their members,<ref name=AWDEvents>{{cite web|url=http://www.allianceofwomendirectors.org/#!page3/cee5|title=AWD Presents|publisher=Alliance of Women Directors|access-date=March 22, 2015}}</ref> and the general public.
The Alliance offers a "TV Shadowing Program" providing opportunities for new directors to learn from experienced directors at work.<ref name=AWDAbout/> The AWD is a nominator for the [[21st Century Fox|Fox]] Global Directors Initiative<ref name=Fox>{{cite web|title=Fox Global Directors Initiative|url=http://www.foxaudiencestrategy.com/directors/|website=Fox Audience Strategy|accessdate=March 18, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315083527/http://www.foxaudiencestrategy.com/directors/|archive-date=2015-03-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><!-- The AWD are listed as a nominating institution under the "WHO ARE THE NOMINATING ORGANIZATIONS FOR FDI?" header--> and an allied organization of the Women Filmmakers Initiative.<ref name=Sundance>{{cite web|title=Exploring the Barriers and Opportunities for Independent Women Filmmakers|last1=Smith|first1=Stacy L.|last2=Pieper|first2=Katherine|last3=Choueiti|first3=Marc|url=http://annenberg.usc.edu/pages/~/media/MDSCI/Exploring-The-Barriers.ashx|publisher= [[USC Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism]]|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref>
The AWD helps its members make professional connections. In 2014, Maria Burton was hired as director of ''A Sort of Homecoming'' <ref>http://www.asortofhomecoming.com</ref> when the film's producer consulted the AWD to find a suitable candidate.<ref name=Time>{{cite journal|title=These Are the Best Unproduced Screenplays with Female Protagonists|last=Rothman|first=Lily|url=http://time.com/4975/athena-list-female-protagonists/|date=February 6, 2014|journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=March 20, 2015}}</ref> In 2008, Victoria Rose Sampson won a competition for her film, ''Need for Speed,'' after being notified about the contest via the Alliance.<ref>{{cite web|last=Harley|first=Bryan|url=http://www.motorcycle-usa.com/321/1955/Motorcycle-Article/H-D-Contest-Winners-Get-Hollywood-Debut.aspx|title=H-D Contest Winners Get Hollywood Debut|website=Motorcycle USA|date=December 16, 2008|accessdate=April 3, 2015}}</ref>
==Views== According to their [[press kit]], the Alliance believes in "foster[ing] a community of professionals to advance the art, craft and visibility of women directors in the world of film, television and new media" and promotes the idea that it is "vital that stories are told from all perspectives".<ref name=AWDPress>{{cite web|url=http://media.wix.com/ugd/b3f9a4_73ff9a1b991fe545f4123a5b0d890891.pdf|title=Press/Media Kit|publisher=Alliance of Women Directors|format=pdf|access-date=March 22, 2015}}</ref> [[Eleonore Dailly]], co-chair of the AWD, in an interview with ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'' magazine, described the group's goals as, "debunk[ing] this myth that there aren't enough female directors. There are highly trained female directors who can handle thrillers and action films just like male directors can handle romantic comedies."<ref name=Elle>{{cite journal|last=Moss|first=Rebecca|url=http://www.elle.com/culture/movies-tv/news/a24941/summer-blockbusters-female-directors/|title=What Does a Female-Directed Blockbuster Look Like?|journal=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]|date=June 30, 2014|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref>
Director [[Maria Burton]] was the co-chair of the Alliance for six years. Describing the problem to the ''[[LA Daily News]]'', Burton said "through all the years, through all the genres, in front and behind the camera, women are vastly underrepresented."<ref name=LADailyNews>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailynews.com/arts-and-entertainment/20150218/women-still-making-few-inroads-in-directing-field|title=Women still making few inroads in directing field|last=Lowman|first=Rob|date=February 18, 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]|publisher=[[MediaNews Group]]|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref> Speaking as an AWD board member, director Jacqui Barcos told ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' on the lack of women-directed films at [[Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]], "complex dramas [...] tend to be difficult to finance in the U.S. If they are complex, the only way to get them financed is to have a big-name director, because then the investors are assured it'll be a masterpiece. And many of the most talented female directors are still relatively unproven, so investors don't want to take a chance."<ref name=HuffPost>{{cite news|title=Cannes' Female Director Problem Highlighted By 2012 Selections|last=Satran|first=Joe|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/19/cannes-film-festival-female-director_n_1438632.html|date=April 19, 2015|website=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref> Similarly, Barcos told ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' that it was important to demonstrate that "a woman director can deliver a commercially successful film that is outside the romantic comedy ghetto".<ref name=Variety2009/>
==Membership and organization== Currently, AWD membership is over 250,<ref name=Var-03-30-16>{{cite news|title=Greg Berlanti, Ilene Chaiken to Be Honored by Alliance of Women Directors|first=Dave|last=McNary|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/greg-berlanti-ilene-chaiken-alliance-of-women-directors-1201741662/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=30 March 2016|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> including Eleonore Dailly,<ref name=Elle/> Judy Chaikin,<ref name=Lehman>{{cite web|url=http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/distributed/D/bo12323805.html|title=Directors: From Stage to Screen and Back Again |publisher=[[The University of Chicago Press]]|accessdate=April 3, 2015}}</ref> director-producer [[Hilari Scarl]],<ref name=AWDAbout/> [[Alexis Krasilovsky]], [[Jen McGowan]], [[Debra Granik]],<ref name=AWDmembers>{{cite web|url=http://www.allianceofwomendirectors.org/#!awd-members/cuc|title=Alliance of Women Directors Members|publisher=Alliance of Women Directors|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref> [[Mimi Leder]], [[Betty Thomas]], [[Bethany Rooney]], and [[Lesli Linka Glatter]].<ref name=Var-03-30-16/> To qualify for AWD membership, an applicant must be a woman who has directed a publicly aired feature film, TV episode, TV movie, documentary, commercial, or short film.<ref name=AWDAbout/> Members pay annual [[union dues|dues]] to support the group's work.<ref name=AWDjoin>{{cite web|url=http://www.allianceofwomendirectors.org/#!join/c7f0|title=Alliance of Women Directors - Join|publisher=Alliance of Women Directors|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref> The AWD is headed by two co-chairs, currently Dailly and [[Jennifer Warren]]. It has a six-person board, a smaller advisory board, as well as honorary members and emeritus board members.<ref name=AWDAbout/>
==Awards==
On April 28, 2016, the AWD held its first ''Alliance of Women Directors Awards'' ceremony at the [[Paley Center for Media]] ([[Beverly Hills]]). Television producers [[Greg Berlanti]] ([[Arrow (TV series)|''Arrow'']], [[Supergirl (TV series)|''Supergirl'']], [[The Flash (2014 TV series)|''The Flash'']]) and [[Ilene Chaiken]] ([[Empire (2015 TV series)|''Empire'']]) were honored for expanding opportunities for women in directing and other behind the camera roles in the television industry.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arrow producer: 'Diversity is not a burden, it’s just smart business'|first=Derek|last=Lawrence|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/04/29/greg-berlanti-ilene-chaiken-gender-equality-hollywood|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=29 April 2016|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> Producers [[Chiara Tilesi]] and [[Albert Berger]] of the We Do It Together foundation were also honored, and director Jen McGowan (''Kelly & Cal'') was awarded the ''AWD Breakout Award''.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Call To Action As Chaiken, Berlanti Honored at Inaugural Alliance of Women Directors Awards|first=David|last=Robb|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/alliance-of-women-directors-awards-ilene-chaiken-greg-berlanti-empire-supergirl-1201746390/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=28 April 2016|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of female film and television directors]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.allianceofwomendirectors.org/}}
[[Category:Women's film organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1997]] [[Category:Women in television]] [[Category:American women film directors| ]] [[Category:Women television directors| ]] [[Category:Professional associations based in the United States]] [[Category:Film organizations in the United States]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Elgin Marbles London.jpg|thumb|right|270px|[[metope (architecture)|Metope]] from the [[Elgin Marbles]].]] [[Image:Human headed winged bull facing.jpg|thumb|240px|right|An [[Assyria]]n [[lamassu]], [[Louvre]].]] [[File:Chinese ritual wine server (guang).jpg|thumb|right|240px|Chinese ritual wine server (''[[Guang (vessel)|guang]]''), c. 1100 BC]] {{otheruses}} '''Antiquities''' are objects from [[Ancient history|antiquity]]<!-- Don't attempt to disam; most meanings are relevant -->, especially the [[civilizations]] of the [[Mediterranean]]: the [[Classical antiquity]] of Greece and Rome, [[Ancient Egypt]] and the other [[Ancient Near East]]ern cultures. Artifacts from earlier periods such as the [[Mesolithic]], and other civilizations from Asia and elsewhere may also be covered by the term. The phenomenon of giving a high value to ancient artifacts is found in other cultures, notably China, where [[Chinese ritual bronzes]], three to two thousand years old, have been avidly collected and imitated for centuries, and the [[Pre-Columbian cultures of Mesoamerica]], where in particular the artifacts of the earliest [[Olmec civilization]] are found reburied in significant sites of later cultures up to the Spanish Conquest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artworld.uea.ac.uk/cms/index.php?q=node/873 |accessdate=August 10, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
==Definition== The definition of the term is not always precise, and institutional definitions such as [[museum]] "Departments of Antiquities" often cover later periods, but in normal usage [[Gothic art|Gothic]] objects, for example, would not now be described as antiquities, though in 1700 they might well have been, as the cut-off date for antiquities has tended to retreat since the word was first found in English in 1513. Non-artistic [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] are now less likely to be called antiquities than in earlier periods. [[Francis Bacon]] wrote in 1605: "Antiquities are history defaced, or some remnants of history which have casually escaped the shipwreck of time".
The art trade reflects modern usage of the term; [[Christie's]] "Department of Antiquities" covers objects "from the dawn of civilization to the [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Ages]], ranging from Western Europe to the Caspian Sea, embracing the cultures of Egypt, Greece, Rome and the Near East."<ref>[http://www.christies.com/departments/ant/overview.asp] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826120013/http://www.christies.com/departments/ant/overview.asp |date=August 26, 2014 }}</ref> [[Bonhams]] use a similar definition: "...4000 B.C to the 12th Century A.D. Geographically they originate from Egypt, the Near East and Europe ..." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bonhams.com/cgi-bin/public.sh/pubweb/publicSite.r?sContinent=usa&Screen=antiquities |title=Antiquities |publisher=Bonhams |date= |accessdate=2014-08-25}}</ref> Official cut-off dates are often later, being unconcerned with precise divisions of [[art history]], and using the term for all historical periods they wish to protect: in [[Jordan]] it is 1750,<ref>[http://conference.legadoandalusi.es/en/doa1.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927202717/http://conference.legadoandalusi.es/en/doa1.htm |date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref> in [[Antiquities and Monuments Ordinance|Hong Kong]] 1800, and so on.
The term is no longer much used in formal academic discussion, because of this imprecision. However, a recent attempt to standardise this and other terms has been carried out.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://saa.uaic.ro/from-antiquities-to-memorabilia-a-standardised-terminology-for-ancestral-artefacts-according-to-manufacture-date/|title=From antiquities to memorabilia: a standardised terminology for ancestral artefacts according to manufacture date|first=Policarp|last=HORTOLÀ|date=1 December 2017|journal=Studia Antiqua et Archaeologica|volume=23|issue=2|accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> Most, but not all, antiquities have been recovered by [[archaeology]]. There is little or no overlap with [[antiques]], which covers objects, not generally discovered as a result of archaeology, at most about three hundred years old, and usually far less.
==History== The sense of ''antiquitates'', the idea that a civilization could be recovered by a systematic exploration of its [[relic]]s and [[material culture]], in the sense used by [[Varro]] and reflected in [[Josephus]]' ''[[Antiquities of the Jews]]'' was lost during the Middle Ages, when ancient objects were collected with other appeals, the rarity or strangeness of their materials or simply because they were thought to be endowed with magical or [[Miracle|miraculous]] powers.<ref>Roberto Weiss, 1969. ''The Renaissance Discovery of Classical Antiquity'', p. 2ff.</ref> Precious [[Cameo (carving)|cameo]]s and other antique [[carved gem]]s might be preserved when incorporated into crowns and diadems and liturgical objects,<ref>The "[[Cup of the Ptolemies]]" was set in Carolingian precious mounting and preserved in the [[Basilica of Saint-Denis]].</ref> [[Diptych|consular ivory diptych]]s by being used as gospel covers. Roman columns could be re-erected in churches.<ref>Robert Weiss notes (1969:8) that Ionic columns from the [[Baths of Caracalla]] were used in Innocent II's rebuilding of [[Santa Maria in Trastevere]], 1139</ref> [[Sarcophagus|sarcophagi]] could receive new occupants and [[Urn|cinerary urn]]s could function as holy water [[stoup]]s. Sculptural representations of the human form, feared and reviled as "[[Cult image|idols]]" could be rehabilitated by reidentifying their subjects: the [[Equestrian Statue of Marcus Aurelius|equestrian bronze Marcus Aurelius]] of the Campidoglio was respected as a representation of the Christian emperor [[Constantine I|Constantine]], and in Pavia the [[Regisole]] acquired a civic role that preserved it. In Rome the Roman bronze ''[[Boy with Thorn|Spinario]]'' was admired for itself by the guidebook writer [[Magister Gregorius]]. The classicism of the [[Carolingian renaissance]] was in part inspired by appreciation of [[Late Antiquity|Late Antique]] manuscripts: the [[Utrecht Psalter]] attempts to recreate such a Late Antique original, both in its handwriting and its illustrations.<ref>Noted in this context by Roberto Weiss 1969:4.</ref>
Many museums hold these artifacts and keep them safe so that we have access to the knowledge they hold about the past. On September 2nd the National Museum of Brazil was engulfed in flames. This event caused many artifacts to be lost forever. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/leaders/2018/09/08/lessons-from-the-destruction-of-the-national-museum-of-brazil|title=Lessons from the destruction of the National Museum of Brazil|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-09-12|language=en}}</ref>
==Illegal trading== [[Image:Euphronios krater side B MET L.2006.10.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The [[Euphronios krater]] has been returned to Italy by the [[Metropolitan Museum]]]] The export of antiquities is now heavily controlled by law in almost all countries and by the [[UNESCO Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property|1970 UNESCO Convention]] on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/culture/themes/illicit-trafficking-of-cultural-property|title=Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property|publisher=Unesco.org|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> but a large and increasing trade in [[Illicit antiquities]] continues. The [[Euphronios krater]] is an apparent example that has come to light.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brodie|first=Neil|title=Euphronios (Sarpedon) Krater|url=http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/euphronios-sarpedon-krater|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref> Another example is the ambiguous legal case concerning the [[Getty Museum]]'s "Bronze Statue of a Victorious Youth".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://illicit-cultural-property.blogspot.co.uk/2007/03/bronze-statue-of-victorious-youth.html|title=The "Bronze Statue of a Victorious Youth"|author=|date=|website=illicit-cultural-property.blogspot.co.uk|accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> The field has been further complicated by the trade in [[Archaeological forgery|Archaeological forgeries]], such as the [[Etruscan terracotta warriors]], the [[Persian Princess]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Brodie|first=Neil|title=Persian Mummy|url=http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/persian-mummy/|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref> and the [[Getty kouros]].
==See also== {{Collecting Hobby}} *[[Ancient art]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Ancient art]] [[Category:Art genres]] [[Category:Archaeological artifacts]] [[Category:Art and cultural repatriation]]

{{Infobox company | name = Atlas Talent Agency |logo= |caption= | type = [[Privately held company]] | genre = | foundation = January 1, 2001 | founder = [[Lisa Marber-Rich]]
[[John Hossenlopp]]
[[Jonn Wasser]]
[[Ian Lesser]] | location_city = New York City | location_country = USA | key_people = | industry = Commercial Talent | products = Voiceover Talent, On-Camera Talent | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.atlastalent.com/ Atlas Talent Agency] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Atlas Talent Agency''' is an American commercial talent agency,http://www.backstage.com/resources/detail/agent/atlas-talent-agency-54524/ specializing in [[voiceover]] talent. The agency was founded in [[New York, New York|New York City]] on January 1, 2000 when three agents at Don Buchwald and Associates{{cite web|url=http://www.buchwald.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141126052153/http://www.buchwald.com/ |archivedate=2014-11-26 |df= }} left to form their own commercial agency. The West Hollywood office opened in 2010. ==Notable acting clients== *[[Kathy Bates]] *[[Giancarlo Esposito]] *[[Judd Hirsch]] *[[Frank Langella]] *[[Lisa Loeb]] *[[Matt McGorry]] *[[Dee Snider]] *[[Marlo Thomas]] *[[Lily Tomlin]] *[[Suzanne Vega]] *[[Liza Weil]] ==Notable voice acting clients== *[[Bob Bergen]] *[[Victor Brandt]] *[[Phil Buckman]] *[[Jim Cummings]] *[[John Cygan]] *[[Gideon Emery]] *[[Manoel Felciano]] *[[Dwayne Hill]] *[[Misty Lee]] *[[Amanda C. Miller]] *[[Michelle Ruff]] *[[Stephanie Sheh]] *[[Kim Strauss]] *[[Paula Tiso]] *[[Hynden Walch]] *[[Tay Zonday]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.atlastalent.com/ Official Website] * [https://www.imdb.com/company/co0052267/ IMDB Profile] [[Category:2001 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Companies based in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]] [[Category:Companies established in 2001]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of the United States]] [[Category:Talent and literary agencies]]

revision.text:
{{for|people who make animated cartoons|animator}} {{merge from|comics artist|date=July 2018}} {{Comics navbar |title = Cartoonist |image = Jack Elrod.jpg |caption = Cartoonist [[Jack Elrod (cartoonist)|Jack Elrod]] at work on a [[Sunday comics|Sunday page]] of the ''[[Mark Trail]]'' comic strip }} A '''cartoonist''' (also '''comic strip creator''') is a visual artist who specializes in drawing [[cartoon]]s. This work is often created for entertainment, political commentary, or advertising. Cartoonists may work in many formats, such as [[book]]lets, [[comic strip]]s, [[comic book]]s, [[editorial cartoons]], [[graphic novel]]s, [[User guide|manuals]], [[gag cartoon]]s, [[graphic design]], [[illustrations]], [[storyboards]], [[posters]], [[shirts]], [[books]], [[advertisements]], [[greeting cards]], [[magazines]], [[newspapers]], and [[video game packaging]].
==History==
===In the West===
The English [[satire|satirist]] and editorial cartoonist [[William Hogarth]], who emerged In the 18th century, has been credited with pioneering Western [[sequential art]]. His work ranged from [[Realism (visual arts)|realistic]] portraiture to [[comic strip]]-like series of pictures called "modern moral subjects". Much of his work poked fun at contemporary politics and customs; illustrations in such style are often referred to as "Hogarthian".<ref>[http://www.britishmuseumshoponline.org/invt/brimus068?stylecat=art_prints The British Museum. Beer Street, William Hogarth - Fine Art Print] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100303011009/http://www.britishmuseumshoponline.org/invt/brimus068?stylecat=art_prints |date=2010-03-03 }} Retrieved 11 April 2010.</ref> Following the work of Hogarth, [[political cartoons]] began to develop in England in the latter part of the 18th century under the direction of its great exponents, [[James Gillray]] and [[Thomas Rowlandson]], both from London. Gillray explored the use of the medium for lampooning and [[caricature]], calling the king (George III), prime ministers and generals to account, and has been referred to as the father of the political cartoon.<ref>{{cite news|title=Satire, sewers and statesmen: why James Gillray was king of the cartoon|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/mar/21/satire-sewers-and-statesmen-james-gillray-king-of-cartoon|agency=The Guardian|date=16 June 2015}}</ref>
While never a professional cartoonist, [[Benjamin Franklin]] is credited with having the first cartoon published in an American newspaper.{{sfn|Hess|Northrop|2011|p=24}} In the 19th century, professional cartoonists such as [[Thomas Nast]] introduced other familiar American political symbols, such as the [[Republican Party (United States)#Name and symbols|Republican elephant]].{{sfn|Hess|Northrop|2011|p=24}}
[[File:Benjamin Franklin - Join or Die.jpg|thumb|alt=Cartoon of a snake severed in eight pieces, each piece labeled with the initials of an American colony. The caption reads, ''Join, or Die''.|[[Benjamin Franklin]]'s ''[[Join, or Die]]'' (1754), credited as the first cartoon published in an American newspaper.]]
[[File:Charles Dana Gibson 02.jpg|left|thumb|alt=A man in late middle-age, facing left, drawing at an upright drawing board.|[[Charles Dana Gibson]] was an influential American cartoonist in the early 20th century.]] During the [[20th century]], numerous magazines carried single-panel gag cartoons by such [[Freelancer|freelance]] cartoonists as [[Charles Addams]], [[Irwin Caplan]], [[Chon Day]], [[Clyde Lamb]], and [[John Norment]]. These were almost always published in black and white, although ''[[Collier's Weekly|Collier's]]'' often carried cartoons in color. The debut of ''[[Playboy]]'' introduced full-page color cartoons by [[Jack Cole (artist)|Jack Cole]], [[Eldon Dedini]], [[Roy Raymonde]] and others. Single-panel cartoonists syndicated to newspapers included [[Dave Breger]], [[Hank Ketcham]], [[George Lichty]], [[Fred Neher]], [[Irving Phillips]], and [[J. R. Williams (cartoonist)|J. R. Williams]].
==Comics==
Comic strips received widespread distribution to mainstream newspapers by [[Print syndication|syndicates]]<ref name="www.comicsreporter.com">{{Cite web | last = | first = | title = The Comics Reporter | url = http://www.comicsreporter.com/index.php/all_about_comics/all_about/76/ | publisher = | date = | accessdate = 17 November 2009 }}</ref> such as the [[Universal Press Syndicate]], [[United Media]], or [[King Features Syndicate|King Features]]. [[Sunday strip]]s go to a [[colorist|coloring]] company such as American Color before they are published.
Some comic strip creators publish in the [[alternative media|alternative press]] or on the [[Internet]]. Comic strip artists may also sometimes work in book-length form, creating [[graphic novel]]s. Both vintage and current strips receive reprints in book collections.
The major comic book publishers (such as [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] or [[DC Comics|DC]]) utilize teams of cartoonists to produce the art (typically separating pencil work, inking and lettering while the color is added digitally by [[colorist]]s). When a consistent artistic style is wanted among different cartoonists (such as [[Archie Comics]]), character [[model sheet]]s may be used as reference.
Calum MacKenzie, in his preface to the exhibition catalog, ''The Scottish Cartoonists'' (Glasgow Print Studio Gallery, 1979) defined the selection criteria: :The difference between a cartoonist and an illustrator was the same as the difference between a comedian and a comedy actor—the former both deliver their own lines and take full responsibility for them, the latter could always hide behind the fact that it was not his entire creation.<ref>MacKenzie, Calum. ''The Scottish Cartoonists''. Glasgow Print Studio Gallery, 1979.</ref>
[[File:Winsor McCay - Little Nemo film still - drawing.jpg|thumb|alt=A hand holding a pen draws a portly cartoon figure on paper.|Dip pens have traditionally been a popular drawing tool for cartoonists.]]
There are many books of cartoons in both paperback and hardcover, such as the collections of cartoons from ''The New Yorker''. Prior to the 1960s, cartoons were mostly ignored by museums and art galleries. In 1968, the cartoonist and comedian [[Roger Price (comedy)|Roger Price]] opened the first New York City gallery devoted exclusively to cartoons, mainly work by the leading magazine gag cartoonists. Today, there are several museums devoted to cartoons, notably the [[Billy Ireland Cartoon Library & Museum]], run by curator Jenny E. Robb at [[Ohio State University]].
==Creation== Comics artists usually sketch a drawing in pencil before going over the drawing in [[India ink]], using either a [[dip pen]] or a [[brush]]. Artists may also use a [[lightbox]] to create the final image in ink. Some artists, [[Brian Bolland]], for example, use computer graphics, with the published work as the first physical appearance of the artwork. By many definitions (including McCloud's, above), the definition of comics extends to [[digital media]] such as [[webcomic]]s and the [[mobile comic]].
The nature of the comics work being created determines the number of people who work on its creation, with successful [[comic strip]]s and [[comic book]]s being produced through a [[studio]] system, in which an artist assembles a team of assistants to help create the work. However, works from independent companies, [[Self-publishing|self-publishers]], or those of a more personal nature can be produced by a single creator.
Within the comic book industry of North America, the studio system has come to be the main method of creation. Through its use by the industry, the roles have become heavily codified, and the managing of the studio has become the company's responsibility, with an editor discharging the management duties. The editor assembles a number of creators and oversees the work to publication.
Any number of people can assist in the creation of a comic book in this way, from a [[Plot (narrative)|plotter]], a [[Script breakdown|breakdown artist]], a [[penciller]], an [[inker]], a [[writer|scripter]], a [[letterer]], and a [[colorist]], with some roles being performed by the same person.
In contrast, a comic strip tends to be the work of a sole creator, usually termed a cartoonist. However, it is not unusual for a cartoonist to employ the studio method, particularly when a strip become successful. [[Mort Walker]] employed a studio, while [[Bill Watterson]] and [[Charles Schulz]] did not. Gag, political, and editorial cartoonists tend to work alone as well, though a cartoonist may use assistants.
==Web cartoonist== Many artists have used the web since its inception to publish their works online. This eventually led to the creation of [[webcomics]] thanks in part to many titles being able to be read for free and anyone being able to publish them. Many of the artists who create these webcomics are known as '''web cartoonists''' due to the fact that the vast majority of webcomics are considered to be online versions of comic-strips and cartoons rather than full-fledged comic books like [[digital comics]]. It is hard to pinpoint when the actual term was created but the earliest use was 2001 with the [[Web Cartoonists' Choice Awards]]. Some well known web cartoonists include [[Randall Munroe]] of ''[[xkcd]]'', [[Jeph Jacques]] of ''[[Questionable Content]]'' and [[Jerry Holkins]] and [[Mike Krahulik]] of ''[[Penny Arcade]]''.
==Art styles== [[Image:ScottMcCloud Angouleme2000.jpg|right|thumb|[[Scott McCloud]], whose work ''[[Understanding Comics]]'' identified the different styles of art used within comics.]] While almost all comics art is in some sense abbreviated, and also while every artist who has produced comics work brings their own individual approach to bear, some broader art styles have been identified. Comic strip artists [[Cliff Sterrett]], [[Frank King (cartoonist)|Frank King]], and [[Gus Arriola]] often used unusual, colorful backgrounds, sometimes veering into abstract art.
The basic styles have been identified as [[Realism (visual arts)|realistic]] and cartoony, with a huge middle ground for which R. Fiore has coined the phrase liberal. Fiore has also expressed distaste with the terms realistic and cartoony, preferring the terms literal and freestyle, respectively.{{sfn|Fiore|2010}}
Scott McCloud has created "The Big Triangle"<ref name="ref48">{{cite web|url=http://www.scottmccloud.com/4-inventions/triangle/index.html |title=The Big Triangle |publisher=scottmccloud.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-06}}</ref> as a tool for thinking about comics art. He places the realistic representation in the bottom left corner, with iconic representation, or cartoony art, in the bottom right, and a third identifier, [[abstraction (art)|abstraction]] of image, at the apex of the triangle. This allows placement and grouping of artists by [[triangulation]]. * The cartoony style uses comic effects and a variation of line widths for expression. Characters tend to have rounded, simplified anatomy. Noted exponents of this style are [[Carl Barks]] and [[Jeff Smith (cartoonist)|Jeff Smith]].{{sfn|Fiore|2010}} * The realistic style, also referred to as the adventure style is the one developed for use within the adventure strips of the 1930s. They required a less cartoony look, focusing more on realistic anatomy and shapes, and used the [[illustrations]] found in [[pulp magazines]] as a basis. This style became the basis of the superhero comic book style since [[Joe Shuster]] and [[Jerry Siegel]] originally worked ''[[Superman]]'' up for publication as an adventure strip.<ref name="ref47">Santos, 1998. [https://web.archive.org/web/19981205234346/http://www.dereksantos.com/comicpage/gold.html The Golden Era... June 1938 to 1945, Part I]</ref>
McCloud also notes that in several traditions, there is a tendency to have the main characters drawn rather simplistic and cartoony, while the backgrounds and environment are depicted realistically. Thus, he argues, the reader easily identifies with the characters, (as they are similar to one's idea of self), whilst being immersed into a world, that's three-dimensional and textured.{{sfn|McCloud|1993|p=48}} Good examples of this phenomenon include [[Hergé]]'s ''[[The Adventures of Tintin]]'' (in his "personal trademark" [[Ligne claire]] style), [[Will Eisner]]'s ''[[Spirit (comics)|Spirit]]'' and [[Osamu Tezuka]]'s ''[[Buddha (manga)|Buddha]]'', among many others.
===Tools=== Artists use a variety of pencils, paint brushes, or paper, typically [[Bristol board]], and a waterproof [[ink]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creativebloq.com/art/16-essential-art-tools-artists-41619768|title=16 essential art tools for artists|publisher=}}</ref> When inking, many artists preferred to use a [[Winsor & Newton]] Series 7, #3 brush as the main tool, which could be used in conjunction with other brushes, dip pens, a [[fountain pen]], and/or a variety of [[technical pen]]s or [[marker pen|markers]]. [[Tints and shades|Mechanical tints]] can be employed to add grey tone to an image. An artist might paint with [[acrylic paint|acrylics]], [[gouache]], [[poster paint]]s, or [[Watercolor painting|watercolors]]. Color can also be achieved through crayons, pastels or colored pencils.
[[Eraser]], [[ruler]]s, templates, [[set square]]s and a [[T-square]] assist in creating lines and shapes. A [[drawing board|drawing table]] provides an angled work surface with lamps sometimes attached to the table. A [[light box]] allows an artist to trace his pencil work when inking, allowing for a looser finish. [[Knives]] and [[scalpel]]s fill a variety of needs, including cutting board or scraping off mistakes. A cutting mat aids paper trimming. Process white is a thick opaque white material for covering mistakes. [[Adhesive]]s and [[Adhesive tape|tapes]] help composite an image from different sources.
==See also== {{portal|Comics|Cartoon}} {{div col|colwidth=50em}} *[[Comic book creator]] *[[Editorial cartoonist]] *[[Harvey Award]] *[[List of cartoonists]] *[[List of newspaper comic strips]] *[[Mangaka]] *''[[The Someday Funnies]]'' *[[Webcomic]] *[[Female comics creators|Women in comics]]
{{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|50em}}
===Works cited=== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite book |ref = harv |last1 = Hess |first1 = Stephen |last2 = Northrop |first2 = Sandy |title = American Political Cartoons: The Evolution of a National Identity, 1754-2010 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=04VY36Q_OxAC |year = 2011 |publisher = Transaction Publishers |isbn = 978-1-4128-1119-4}} {{Refend}}
==Further reading== * Steve Edgell, Tim Pilcher, Brad Brooks, ''The Complete Cartooning Course: Principles, Practices, Techniques'' (London: Barron's, 2001).
==External links== {{Wiktionary|Cartoonist}} {{commonscat|Cartoonists}}
===Societies and organizations=== *[http://www.procartoonists.org/ Professional Cartoonists' Organisation (UK)] *[http://www.reuben.org/ National Cartoonists Society] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070701020627/http://editorialcartoonists.com/ Association of American Editorial Cartoonists] *[http://www.societyillustrators.org/ Society of Illustrators] *[http://www.scbwi.org/ Society of Children’s Book Writers and Illustrators] *[http://www.si-la.org/ Society of Illustrators of Los Angeles] *[http://www.theaoi.com/ The Association of Illustrators] *[http://www.illustratorspartnership.org/ The Illustrators Partnership of America] *[http://www.illustrationquebec.com/ AIIQ - l’Association des Illustrateurs et Illustratrices du Québec] *[http://www.allianceofillustrators.org/ Colorado Alliance of Illustrators] *[http://www.archaeologists.net/groups/graphics Institute For Archaeologists Graphics Archaeology Group] *[http://www.gnsi.org/ Guild of Natural Science Illustrators] *[http://www.gnsinw.org/ Guild of Natural Science Illustrators-Northwest] *[http://www.illustratorsaustralia.com/ Illustrators Australia] *[http://www.newsart.com/ Newsart] *[http://www.cartoonists.org.au/ Australian Cartoonists Association]
===Communities=== *[https://www.cartoonistclub.com/ Cartoonist Club] *[http://www.deviantart.com/ DeviantART] *[http://www.conceptart.org/ ConceptArt] *[http://www.toonsup.com/ toonsUp] *[http://mojizu.com/ Mojizu] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100612162153/http://illustrateur.org/ Illustrateur] *[http://www.hollywood-popart.com/ Comic Design] *[http://www.steamkat.com/ SteamKat]
{{Comics}} {{Pens}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox Historic Site | name = Crypt Chambers| native_name = | image = Crypt Chambers 1.jpg| image_size = 200| caption = Crypt Chambers| locmapin = Cheshire| map_width = 200| map_caption = Location in Cheshire | coordinates = {{coord|53.19046|-2.89031|scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | gbgridref = SJ 406,663| location = 28–34 Eastgate Street and 34–40 Eastgate Row, [[Chester]], Cheshire, England| area = | elevation = | formed = | founded = | built = 1858 | built_for = William and Charles Brown| demolished = | rebuilt = | restored = | restored_by = | architect = [[Thomas Mainwaring Penson|T. M. Penson]]| architecture = [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]]| visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = | designation1 = Grade I| designation1_offname = No.28 Street and No.34 Row (Crypt Building)| designation1_type = | designation1_criteria = | designation1_date = 28 July 1955| delisted1_date = | designation1_parent = | designation1_number = | designation1_free1name = | designation1_free1value = | designation1_free2name = | designation1_free2value = | designation1_free3name = | designation1_free3value = }}
'''Crypt Chambers''' (or '''Crypt Building''') is at 28–34 Eastgate Street and 34–40 Eastgate Row, [[Chester]], Cheshire, England. It is recorded in the [[National Heritage List for England]] as a designated Grade I [[Listed building#England and Wales|listed building]] and incorporates a section of the [[Chester Rows]].<ref name=images>{{NHLE |num= 1376232|desc= Number 34 Row Crypt Building 34, Chester|access-date= 15 July 2012 |mode=cs2}}</ref>
==History==
Crypt Chambers is built on the site of a [[England in the Middle Ages|medieval]] house whose [[undercroft]] is still present.<ref>{{Citation | last = Hartwell | first = Clare |last2 = Hyde | first2 = Matthew |last3 = Hubbard | first3 = Edward | author3-link=Edward Hubbard | last4 =Pevsner | first4 =Nikolaus | author4-link =Nikolaus Pevsner | series= The Buildings of England| title = Cheshire |edition= | publisher =[[Yale University Press]]| year =2011| origyear=1971| location =New Haven and London| page = 257| isbn =978-0-300-17043-6 }}</ref> The present building was constructed in 1858 to a design by [[Thomas Mainwaring Penson|T. M. Penson]]. It was built as a [[department store]] for William and Charles Brown of the [[Browns of Chester]] family of [[draper]]s.<ref name=images/> [[File:Browns entrance.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the undercroft|alt=Two columns with a railing between, under which is a stairway leading from the street to a lower level]]
==Architecture== ===Exterior===
The building is in four storeys plus attics. It is constructed in red and yellow [[sandstone]] with a roof of brown tiles. The [[Facade|façade]] is asymmetrical, having a square stair [[turret]], with three bays to the east and one wider bay to the west. At the street level five steps at the base of the tower lead down to the undercroft and in the middle east bay eight steps lead up to the Row level. Between these are shop fronts. At the Row level are [[cast iron]] railings behind which are stallboards and above them are [[Molding (decorative)|moulded]] arches. On the front of the tower at this level is a blank scroll, on the east face is a recessed panel containing the initials W. B. (for William Brown), on the west face the initials are C. B. (for Charles Brown) and on the rear face is a scroll inscribed AD 1858: CRYPT CHAMBERS. On each side of the entrance to the shop are the Chester City [[Coat of arms|arms]]. In each of the third and fourth storeys of the east bays are three pairs of arched, two-light windows with slender columns between each pair. In the west bay are four two-light arched windows in each storey. At this level on the tower is a two-storey [[oriel window]]. Above these storeys, the central eastern bay has a [[gable]] containing a [[Tracery|traceried]] window in a [[Reuleaux triangle|rounded triangle]], on each side of which are three-light [[dormer]] windows. The west bay also has a gable; this contains a small triangular oriel. The tower has a four-light window between shallow [[buttress]]es. The top of the tower consists of a [[Truncation (geometry)|truncated]] [[spire]] with a gabled dormer on each face. At its summit is a cast iron rail.<ref name=images/>
===Interior=== The undercroft consists of four bays with [[chamfer]]ed [[Rib vault|rib-vaulting]]; the [[masonry]] is "of high quality".<ref name=images/> The architectural historian [[Nikolaus Pevsner]] considered its undercroft to be "one of the best medieval crypts of Chester".<ref>{{Citation | last =Pevsner | first =Nikolaus | authorlink =Nikolaus Pevsner | last2 = Hubbard | first2 = Edward | author2-link=Edward Hubbard | series= The Buildings of England| title = Cheshire |edition= | publisher =[[Yale University Press]]| year =2003| origyear=1971| location =New Haven and London| page = 163| isbn =0-300-09588-0 }}</ref> Much of the structure above the undercroft has been changed or covered by modern materials.<ref name=images/>
==Present day==
Crypt Chambers still contains a department store, [[Debenhams]], which maintains its traditional name of Browns of Chester.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.debenhams.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/category_10001_10001_65599_-1| title = My Store: Chester – Browns of Chester | accessdate = 4 August 2009| publisher = [[Debenhams]]}}</ref> The undercroft is used as a restaurant.<ref>{{Citation | last = Morriss| first = Richard| author-link = | year = 1993| title = The Buildings of Chester| publication-place = Dover| publisher = Alan Sutton| page = 19 | id = | isbn = 0-7509-0255-8}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Cheshire}} *[[Grade I listed buildings in Cheshire West and Chester]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Commercial buildings completed in 1858]] [[Category:Grade I listed buildings in Chester]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Department stores of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Gothic Revival architecture in Cheshire]] [[Category:Thomas Mainwaring Penson buildings]]

{{Infobox artist | name = Daku | image =Daku Artist Sign Goregaon Mumbai.jpg | caption =Graffiti of Daku on footbridge in Goregaon, Mumbai | birth_name = Real name: unknown | birth_date = Date of birth: unknown | birth_place = Birthplace: unknown | awards = |website = {{URL|http://www.daku156.com}} | field = [[Graffiti]]
[[Street art]]
[[Social commentary]] | training = }} '''''Daku''''' is a [[pseudonym]]ous [[Street artist|graffiti artist]] from [[Delhi]], India.{{cite web | last=Singh | first=Isha | title=Meet India’s Banksy | website=WSJ | date=27 April 2013 | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/04/27/meet-indias-banksy/ | accessdate=16 February 2015}}{{cite web | title=Pretty as a picture: India Art Fair 2015 | website=The Sunday Guardian | date=9 August 2015 | url=http://www.sunday-guardian.com/artbeat/pretty-as-a-picture-india-art-fair-2015 | accessdate=9 August 2015}} Active since 2008, he painted art in several cities of India. ==Early life== The real identity of Daku is not known. Not much is known about his life. He is possibly born around 1984. He was raised in a small town in [[Saurashtra (region)|Saurashtra]], [[Gujarat]]. He studied art and worked with an advertising agency before starting graffiti. ''Daku'' literally means "bandit" or "[[dacoit]]" in Hindi.{{cite web | title='India's Banksy' wants to provoke voters | website=BBC News | date=7 April 2014 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-26930400 | accessdate=16 February 2015}}{{cite web | last=Bordewekar | first=Sandhya | title=Graffiti Art: The Emergence of Daku on Indian Streets | date=29 November 2014 | url=http://www.artnewsnviews.com/view-article.php?article=graffiti-art-the-emergence-of-daku-on-indian-streets&iid=33&articleid=982 | accessdate=16 February 2015}} ==Career== {{quote|[The street art is] decorative, contextual, layered and artists aren’t afraid of giving their name. Graffiti is more underground, more rebel.|''Daku'', Wall Street Journal, 2013}} He was introduced to graffiti in 2006 through a website called ''Streetfiles''. His initial collaboration was with France-based artist JonOne, one of the founder-members of ''Crew 156'' — the group of popular New York subway artists from the 1980s, in [[Mumbai]] in 2008 for a year.{{Cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/H4VKicbDZlm32BrZZRCTzN/On-15-May-this-art-will-disappear.html|title=On 15 May, this art will disappear|last=Parakala|first=Vangmayi|date=2016-05-06|work=Live Mint|access-date=2017-05-31|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} He also collaborated with two other graffiti artist, Bond and Zine in Delhi in 2008. He started tagging his own name in [[Devnagari script]] on walls in Mumbai and South Delhi in 2008 and told that he did it to reach large Indian population who understand only local languages. He [[stencil]]ed ''fuck'' in Hindi across nine places in Mumbai overnight in 2011 to protest against [[Vasant Dhoble]], assistant commissioner of police who was accused of [[moral police|moral policing]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/lifestyle/books-and-art/111116/the-dacoit-of-the-art-world.html|title=The dacoit of the art world|last=Praveen|first=Priyanka|date=2016-11-11|work=Deccan Chronicle|access-date=2017-08-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170804134138/http://www.deccanchronicle.com/lifestyle/books-and-art/111116/the-dacoit-of-the-art-world.html|archive-date=2017-08-04|dead-url=|language=en}} He regularly commented on social issues by his works like stenciled LPG cylinder rocket to highlight price rise, blindfolded protester during [[2011 Indian anti-corruption movement]].{{cite web | last=Nevatia | first=Shreevatsa | title=Rinky on the wall | website=The Hindu Business Line | date=7 November 2014 | url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/takeaway/rinky-on-the-wall/article6573983.ece | accessdate=9 August 2015}} Before [[2010 Commonwealth Games]] in Delhi, he modified several stop signs to deliver messages and provoke reaction from public. He tagged many garbage bins with ''Ku'' ''Da'' in Delhi, an anagram of his own name. For years he tags his name ''Daku'' across cities in India in indigenous fonts and typography including Mumbai, Delhi, [[Ahmedabad]] and [[Baroda]]. He along with others, did 200 meter long and seven meter high wall graffiti, commissioned at [[Buddh International Circuit]]. He along with Bond, created 200 square meter graffiti at [[IIT Bombay]] TechFest in 2011.{{cite web | title=Cans & Roses: Guerrilla artists on Indian street | website=The Economic Times | date=18 August 2012 | url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-08-18/news/33261718_1_graffiti-artists-yantr-street-art | accessdate=16 February 2015}}{{cite web | title=Street art breathes a new life into Mumbai — Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis | website=dna | date=7 December 2014 | url=http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-street-art-breathes-a-new-life-into-mumbai-2041757 | accessdate=9 August 2015}} Before [[Indian general election, 2014]], he painted a graffiti ''Mat Do'' at F-block, [[Connaught Place, New Delhi|Connaught Place]] which had dual meaning, ''don’t give vote'' or ''vote''. It showed a fisted hand with an inked middle finger.{{cite web | title=A pithy message on the wall | website=Deccan Herald | date=25 March 2015 | url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/467752/a-pithy-message-wall.html | accessdate=9 August 2015}} Daku has created street arts with light, shadows and reflections. He first experimented during Kochi biennale, 2012 and put mirrors to reflect texts such as “Time Flies” or “Time Travel” for limited time in a day. He installed a shadow art in Lodhi Colony, Delhi in March 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/12/arts/daku-india-street-art/index.html|title=Graffiti powered by the sun. What?!|last=CNN|first=Roshni Majumdar|website=CNN|access-date=2017-05-31}} He organized India's first-ever street art festival in Delhi in 2013.{{cite web | title=A new breed of artists is taking their canvases to public spaces | website=India Today | date=19 March 2013 | url=http://m.indiatoday.in/story/street-art-artists-writing-on-wallcanvases-to-public-spaces/1/258036.html | accessdate=16 February 2015}} His works have been showcased at venues such as the [[Centre Pompidou]], [[Venice Biennale]] and Triennale Design museum.{{cite web|title=St+ART Delhi 2015 |website=St+ART Delhi 2015 |date=4 November 2014 |url=http://www.st-artdelhi.org/artists/ |accessdate=16 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216233058/http://www.st-artdelhi.org/artists/ |archivedate=16 February 2015 |df= }} He participated in the India Art Fair 2015 and created 100-meter-long stencilled mural on asphalt with the repeated slogan, ''This is commissioned vandalism''.{{cite web | url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/tV6fSSeVmUFXbFoIjVPw3I/Giant-ants-melting-carpets.html | title=Giant ants, melting carpets | date=22 January 2015 | accessdate=9 August 2015 | last=Khurana | first=Chanpreet | website=livemint.com}}{{cite web | url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/BhxK8VUDkGedRbctaXWAFJ/Girish-Shahane-Art-as-investment-is-a-dreadful-idea.html | title=Girish Shahane: ‘Art as investment is a dreadful idea’ | date=10 January 2015 | accessdate=9 August 2015 | last=Kuruvilla | first=Elizabeth | website=livemint.com}}{{cite web | last=Maddox | first=Georgina | title=Alive to the arts | website=The Hindu Business Line | date=30 January 2015 | url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/blink/watch/alive-to-the-arts/article6835033.ece | accessdate=9 August 2015}}{{cite web | last=Shahane | first=Girish | title=The Ideas That Shaped The Special Projects At The India Art Fair | website=The Huffington Post | date=31 January 2015 | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.in/girish-shahane/enhancing-the-stickiness-_b_6583602.html | accessdate=9 August 2015}} He designed a room in flat of [[Hrithik Roshan]] in 2015.{{cite web | last=Mirror | first=Mumbai | title=Reflects action | website=Mumbai Mirror | date=14 May 2015 | url=http://www.mumbaimirror.com/columns/mumbai-001/Reflects-action/articleshow/47273687.cms | accessdate=9 August 2015}} He had done graffiti on shutters of Hysteria, the music merchandise shop, on Church Street, [[Bengaluru]] in late 2015 for "Mohan Kaun?" Project.{{Cite news|url=http://bangaloremirror.indiatimes.com/columns/sunday-read/how-did-bengalurus-church-street-go-from-being-food-drink-central-to-a-hub-of-art-and-often-activism-heres-how/articleshow/58767530.cms?|title=How did Bengaluru's Church Street go from being food, drink central to a hub of art, and often, activism? Here's how - Bangalore Mirror -|work=Bangalore Mirror|access-date=2017-05-31}} He placed billboards across [[Hyderabad]] in April, 2016 in criticism of [[consumerism]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.asianage.com/life/art/121116/the-dacoit-of-the-art-world.html|title=The dacoit of the art world|last=|first=|date=2016-11-13|work=Asian Age|access-date=2017-05-31|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} In October 2016, he pasted giant snail posters across Silicon Valley, Bangaluru to highlight traffic jams.{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/804849/indias-most-famous-graffiti-artist-is-sticking-snails-around-bengaluru-to-mock-its-woefully-slow-traffic/|title=India’s most famous graffiti artist is sticking giant snails around Bengaluru|last=Thomas|first=Maria|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-05-31|language=en-US}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Street Art}} [[Category:Unidentified people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indian graffiti artists]] [[Category:Pseudonymous artists]] [[Category:Political artists]] [[Category:People from Gujarat]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Indian male artists]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Dar El Bahdja | image = | image_alt = | genre = [[Sitcom]] | writer = Oussama Benhassine | director = Djaafar Gacem | starring = Biyouna
Othmane Ben Daouad
Farida Sabounji
Nawal Zmit
Ahmed Amine Dellal
Souhila Maallem
Chems Eddine Lamrani
Blaha Ben Ziane | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = Algeria | language = [[Algerian Arabic]] | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 11 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = SD-BOX | producer = | runtime = 20 min | company = | distributor = | network = Télévision Algérienne | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = {{Start date|df=yes|2013|077|18}} | last_aired = {{End date|df=yes|2013|07|28}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = | production_website = http://www.sd-box.com/ }} '''''Dar El Bahdja''''' ([[Arabic]]: دار البهجة) is an Algerian TV series broadcast during the month of [[Ramadan]] 2013. It is produced by SD-BOX, directed by Djaffar Gacem[http://www.aljazeera.net/home/print/f6451603-4dff-4ca1-9c10-122741d17432/0e25c585-0cbc-497b-b2b3-41576c836fcb "السلطان عاشور" يستقطب المشاهد الجزائري] Retrieved August 08, 2017., dialogued by Mohamed Charchal.[http://www.djazairess.com/elbilad/201677 "دار البهجة" تصالح بين جعفر قاسم و"السيناريست" محمد شرشال] Retrieved August 08, 2017. The series tells the diaries of a popular neighborhood dwellers, problems and events among them in a comedic framework.[http://www.startimes.com/?t=33036781 نجـــــــوم دار البهجــــــة يفتحون قلبهم للخبــــــــــر] Retrieved August 08, 2017.[http://www.ech-chaab.com/ar/%D8%B5%D9%81%D8%AD%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D8%B5%D8%A9/%D8%A8%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AF%D9%8A-%D8%B4%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%A8/item/8598-%D8%AD%D8%B6%D9%80%D9%88%D8%B1-%D9%85%D9%85%D9%8A%D8%B2-%D9%84%D9%84%D9%88%D8%AC%D9%80%D9%88%D9%87-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A%D9%80%D8%A9-%D9%81%D9%80%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%B9%D9%80%D8%A7%D9%84-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B2%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%86%D9%8A%D9%80%D8%A9.html حضـور مميز للوجـوه الشبانيـة فـي الأعـمال التلفزيونيـة] Retrieved August 08, 2017. It premiere on 2013 on [[Télévision Algérienne]], [[A3 (TV channel)|A3]] and [[Canal Algérie]]. == Cast == * Biyouna as Khalti Djouhar * Othmane Ben Daouad as Sliman * Farida Sabounji as Khdaouaj * Nawal Zmit as Turkiya * Ahmed Amine Dellal as Zino * Souhila Maallem as Zina * Chems Eddine Lamrani * Blaha Ben Ziane == References == {{reflist}} {{Portal|Algeria|Television}} [[Category:Algerian television series]] [[Category:Arabic television series]] [[Category:2013 television series debuts]]
