revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use British English|date=July 2018}}
{{Infobox artwork | title = Donald Trump baby balloon | italic title = no | wikidata = | image = Trump Baby Balloon at protest in Parliament Square.jpg | image_upright = | alt = The helium balloon floating outdoors, held by restraining cords, surrounded by protesters, with the Houses of Parliament in the background | caption = The balloon being flown in [[Parliament Square]] in London on 13 July 2018 ([[Westminster Abbey]] is in the top left) | artist = <nowiki>Matt Bonner</nowiki> | completion_date = {{start date|df=yes|2018|07}} | medium = Plastic [[inflatable]] | subject = [[Donald Trump]] | height_metric = 6 | width_metric = | length_metric = | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | weight = | owner = | accession = | website = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }}
During an official visit to the [[United Kingdom]] by [[President of the United States]] [[Donald Trump]], an inflatable caricature of Trump (usually known as the '''Trump Baby''' or less commonly the '''Baby Trump'''<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mackintosh|first1=Eliza|title='Trump Baby' balloon takes flight in London protests |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/07/13/uk/trump-baby-blimp-to-fly-over-uk-parliament-intl/index.html |accessdate=20 November 2018 |work=[[CNN]] }}</ref>) was flown in protest of him, his visit, his [[Racial views of Donald Trump|racial views]], his history of [[Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations|alleged sexual misconduct]], and his [[Political positions of Donald Trump|policies]].<ref name="Yeginsu">{{cite news |last1=Yeginsu |first1=Ceylan |title=‘Trump Baby’ Balloon Takes Flight, as Protests in U.K. Take Off |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/13/world/europe/uk-trump-protest-may.html |accessdate=13 July 2018 |quote=“There’s really nothing positive to say about him,” said James Rice, 24, a student who came to the protest in a wheelchair. |work=[[The New York Times]] }}</ref> The balloon depicts Trump as an angry orange baby holding a [[smartphone]].
The balloon was flown over [[Parliament Square]], [[London]], on 13 July 2018, where the [[Metropolitan Police|police]] estimate that over 100,000 protestors were in attendance,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shute |first1=Joe |last2=Molloy |first2=Mark |title='Trump Baby' blimp flies outside Parliament as thousands of protesters march through London |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/07/13/trump-baby-blimp-flies-outside-parliament-protesters-march-london/ |accessdate=9 August 2018 |work=The Telegraph |date=13 July 2018}}</ref><!--<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/video/london-protests-against-trump-draws-tens-of-thousands-1276270659667 |title=London protests against Trump draws tens of thousands |publisher=NBC News |date=13 July 2018 |accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref>--> and 50,000 more in [[The Meadows (park)|the Meadows]], [[Edinburgh]], the following day, where protests were also held.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Swanson |first1=Ian |title=Thousands march through the Edinburgh to demonstrate against Donald Trump |url=https://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/politics/thousands-march-through-the-edinburgh-to-demonstrate-against-donald-trump-1-4769283 |accessdate=9 August 2018 |work=Edinburgh Evening News |publisher=The Scotsman |date=16 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Although Trump was not visiting Edinburgh, he was spending the weekend at his [[Turnberry (golf course)|Turnberry golf course]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/donald-trump-uk-visit-protest-golf-scotland-turnberry-a8446966.html|title=Thousands protest as Donald Trump plays golf in Scotland|work=The Independent|access-date=19 July 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref> but permission to fly the balloon there was refused by [[Police Scotland]].<ref name="BBC-44806900">{{cite web |title=Turnberry ban for 'Trump Baby' balloon |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-44806900 |work=BBC News|accessdate=13 July 2018 |date=12 July 2018}}</ref>
==Concept==
One of the organisers, Max Wakefield described the balloon protest as being in response to "the rise of [[far-right politics]] that dehumanises people in order to get into power", and saw it as an attempt to introduce some "good British humour" into the political discourse surrounding Trump's visit.<ref name="Penman" /> Wakefield cited the [[Trump administration family separation policy|Trump administration's family separation policy]] and [[United States withdrawal from the Paris Agreement|Trump's withdrawal of the United States from the Paris climate agreement]] as examples of the kind of policies which the protest was targeting.<ref name="Penman" /> Leo Murray, who led the campaign, wrote in its crowdfunding statement:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://inews.co.uk/news/uk/trump-baby-balloon-donald-trump-sadiq-khan/|title=Sadiq Khan's office gives giant 'Trump Baby' permission to fly over anti-Donald Trump protest|last1=Sandhu|first1=Serena|date=5 July 2018|website=The Essential Daily Briefing|publisher=Johnston Publishing Ltd|accessdate=14 July 2018|quote=The petition: Make Trump Baby Fly. Donald Trump is a big, angry baby with a fragile ego and tiny hands. He's also racist demagogue who is a danger to women, immigrants and minorities and a mortal threat to world peace and the very future of life on earth. Moral outrage is water off a duck's back to Trump. But he really seems to hate it when people make fun of him. So when Trump visits the UK on Friday the 13th of July this year, we want to make sure he knows that all of Britain is looking down on him and laughing at him. That's why a group of us have chipped in and raised enough money to have a 6 metre high blimp made by a professional inflatables company, to be flown in the skies over Parliament Square during Trump's visit.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.commondreams.org/news/2018/07/05/after-popular-uproar-20-foot-tall-angry-trump-baby-blimp-gets-okay-fly-over-London|title=After Popular Uproar, 20-Foot-Tall Angry Trump Baby Blimp Gets Okay to Fly Over London During President's UK Visit|publisher=Common Dreams}}</ref>
{{Quote|text=[When] Trump visits the UK on Friday the 13th of July this year, we want to make sure he knows that all of Britain is looking down on him and laughing at him. That's why a group of us have chipped in and raised enough money to have a 6 meter high blimp made by a professional inflatables company, to be flown in the skies over Parliament Square during Trump's visit.}}
The {{convert|6|m|ft|adj=on}} tall, [[helium]]-filled plastic [[inflatable]], also referred to as a "[[Balloon (aeronautics)|balloon]]" or "[[blimp]]", was designed by Matt Bonner and constructed by Imagine Inflatables of [[Leicester]].<ref name="Doyle">{{cite news |last1=Doyle |first1=Liam |title=Trump baby balloon: Who is behind the balloon mocking Donald Trump in London? |url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/988312/Donald-Trump-baby-blimp-creator-US-president-UK-visit-2018 |accessdate=13 July 2018 |work=[[Daily Express]] |date=13 July 2018 }}</ref> It was made after a [[crowdfunding]] campaign on crowdfunder.co.uk<ref>{{cite web |title=Trump Baby |url=https://www.crowdfunder.co.uk/trump-baby |publisher=Crowdfunder}}</ref> raised the GB£16,000 cost of its creation and deployment.<ref name="BBC-44806900" /> It depicts Trump as "an angry orange baby"<ref name="Yeginsu" /> with a snarling mouth,<ref name="TA">{{cite news |title=Donald Trump angry baby balloon to fly over London during UK visit |url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/donald-trump-angry-baby-balloon-to-fly-over-london-during-uk-visit/news-story/59435d33f8dcb6deb44faed278d9e592 |accessdate=13 July 2018 |work=[[The Australian]] |date=6 July 2018}}</ref> tiny hands,<ref name="Khan">{{cite news |last1=Khan |first1=Shehab |title=Everything you need to know about the giant baby Trump balloon |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/trump-uk-visit-latest-baby-balloon-blimp-protest-london-a8445476.html |accessdate=13 July 2018 |work=The Independent}}</ref> wearing a [[nappy]],<ref name="BBC-44806900" /> and holding a [[smartphone]].<ref name="OGrady" />
Organiser Max Wakefield said "The only way that you can make any impact with Donald Trump is to mock him, because you can't engage him in any kind of argument — it never gets anywhere."<ref name="Penman" />
== History == Permission from the [[Greater London Authority]] (GLA), [[Metropolitan Police]] and [[National Air Traffic Service]] (NATS) was required for the balloon to be flown over [[Parliament Square]], the space above which is considered [[restricted airspace]].<ref name="OGrady">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/07/05/a-giant-blimp-depicting-trump-in-a-diaper-is-likely-to-greet-the-u-s-president-when-he-visits-london/|title=A giant blimp depicting Trump in a diaper is likely to greet the U.S. president when he visits London|last=O'Grady|first=Siobhán|date=5 July 2018|website=The Washington Post|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180730170802/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/07/05/a-giant-blimp-depicting-trump-in-a-diaper-is-likely-to-greet-the-u-s-president-when-he-visits-london/|archive-date=30 July 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Permission was granted, allowing it to be flown, while tethered, up to {{convert|30|m|-1}} high, for up to two hours.<ref name="Doyle" /><ref name="OGrady" /><ref name="Penman">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/07/05/626116238/london-mayor-says-trump-baby-blimp-can-fly-in-protest-of-president-s-visit|title=London Mayor Says 'Trump Baby' Blimp Can Fly In Protest Of President Trump's Visit|publisher=[[NPR]] |date=5 July 2018 |first=Maggie |last=Penman}}</ref> Both the GLA's 'City Operations' team and NATS stressed that the nature of the protest did not play a part on their decisions.<ref name="BBC-44767349">{{cite web |title=Reality Check: The rules on protest balloons |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-44767349 |work=BBC News|accessdate=13 July 2018 |date=13 July 2018}}</ref>
After learning of the balloon, Trump remarked, "I guess when they put out blimps to make me feel unwelcome, no reason for me to go to London."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/2155074/baby-blimp-makes-me-feel-unwelcome-london-complains-trump-blaming|title=Trump complains baby balloon makes him feel ‘unwelcome’ in UK|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=14 July 2018}}</ref>
After its appearance in London, the balloon was taken to Edinburgh, where it was flown over [[The Meadows (park)|the Meadows]], a public park near to the city centre, as part of the protests against Trump's two-day-visit to Scotland,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/trump-baby-balloon-giant-blimp-takes-to-the-sky-above-edinburgh-a3887401.html |title=Trump baby balloon: giant blimp takes to the sky above Edinburgh after being transported from London |last=Collier |first=Hatty |date=14 July 2018 |website=London Evening Standard |access-date=14 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180714184319/https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/trump-baby-balloon-giant-blimp-takes-to-the-sky-above-edinburgh-a3887401.html |archive-date=14 July 2018 }}</ref> permission to fly the balloon near [[Turnberry (golf course)|Turnberry golf course]] having been refused.<ref name="BBC-44806900" /> On 17 July 2018, the balloon was tethered outside [[the O2 Arena]] in London during a performance by the American rock band [[Pearl Jam]], with their blessing.<ref name="PJ">{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/8465972/pearl-jam-baby-trump-balloon-london-o2 |title=Baby Trump Balloon Takes Flight Outside Pearl Jam Show in London |date=18 July 2018| accessdate=18 July 2018| work=Billboard}}</ref> Protesters planned on flying the Trump baby balloon in Ireland in November during Trump's visit to the country, however his trip was cancelled.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/baby-trump-balloon-ireland-visit-protests-us-president-trip-a8518466.html|title=The baby Trump balloon is going to Ireland to meet the US president when he visits|work=The Independent|access-date=2 September 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Museums including the [[British Museum]] and the [[Museum of London]] have expressed interest in acquiring or displaying the original balloon.<ref name="MA">{{cite web |title=British Museum in Trump Baby talks |url=https://www.museumsassociation.org/museums-journal/news/18072018-british-museum-in-trump-baby-talks |publisher=[[Museums Association]] |accessdate=19 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=Marshall-180720>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/20/arts/design/trump-baby-balloon-museums.html | title=Britain Wants to Keep Trump. The Baby Version, That Is. | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=20 July 2018 | accessdate=20 July 2018 | first=Alex | last=Marshall}}</ref>
===Sadiq Khan balloon === A month later on 30 August 2018, pictures of a balloon similar to that of Donald Trump's were circulated, this time depicting London's Mayor [[Sadiq Khan]] wearing a bright yellow bikini. The balloon, like the Donald Trump baby balloon, was crowdfunded after £58,000 was raised to create the blimp. Organizers, saying "a certain amount of respect should be afforded to the leader of the free world and the greatest ally the UK has," said the balloon was made "in retaliation" to the Trump balloon.<ref name="SadiqBalloon">{{cite web |last1=Drury |first1=Colin |title=Sadiq Khan balloon: Small crowd gathers to watch £58k blimp of London mayor in yellow bikini |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/sadiq-khan-balloon-london-mayor-blimp-trump-baby-yello-bikini-a8518176.html |website=Independent |accessdate=November 30, 2018}}</ref>It featured Khan wearing a yellow bikini in response to the banning of a series of Protein World advertisements on London's public transport networks, which had shown a woman in a yellow bikini with the slogan "are you beach body ready?". The adverts were criticized for allegedly objectifying women and promoting unrealistic female body images. The adverts were eventually banned, with Sadiq Khan supporting their removal.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jacob Jarvis |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/sadiq-khan-blimp-to-be-flown-over-london-in-protest-at-his-decision-to-allow-trump-baby-to-fly-above-a3923216.html |title=Sadiq Khan balloon will fly over London to protest giant Donald Trump baby blimp | London Evening Standard |publisher=Standard.co.uk |date=13 July 2018 |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> Sadiq Khan commented, "If people want to spend their Saturday looking at me in a yellow bikini they're welcome to do so, I don't really think yellow's my colour though." A small crowd gathered to watch as the blimp flew over London's Parliament Square on 1 September 2018. It has made no further appearances.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-45352622 |title=Giant Sadiq Khan bikini-clad balloon to fly over London - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref><ref name="SadiqBalloon"/>
==Appearances outside of the UK==
===United States===
A group of activists in the United States raised nearly US$24,000 in a [[GoFundMe]] campaign to construct four Trump baby balloons that they planned to fly over [[Trump National Golf Club (Bedminster, New Jersey)|Trump National Golf Club]] in [[Bedminster, New Jersey]]. Initially, they sought US$4,500 to build one balloon, with permission from the designer, but exceeded their goals more than fivefold. Their fund raising was so successful that they were able to make six balloons in all. The balloons are available for "adoption" by groups for events in other states.<ref name="Held-180719">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/07/19/630602022/american-baby-trump-blimp-set-to-breeze-onto-namesakes-home-turf|title=American Baby Trump Blimp Set To Breeze Onto Namesake's Home Turf|last=Held|first=Amy|date=19 July 2018|work=[[NPR]]|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="Williams-180717">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/07/17/politics/trump-baby-blimp-new-jersey-trnd/index.html|title='Baby Trump' balloons are coming to New Jersey after flying in the United Kingdom|last=Williams|first=David|date=17 July 2018|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="Johnson">{{cite web|url=https://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2018/07/baby_trump_balloon_campaign_blows_away_goal_now_th.html|title='Baby Trump' balloon campaign blows away goal. Now they're having quadruplets|last=Johnson|first=Alexis|last2=Brodesser-Akner|first2=Claude|date=18 July 2018|work=NJ.com|accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref> Copies of the "Baby Trump", sometimes referred to as the "baby [[blimp]]", balloon have appeared across the U.S. in Florida, Michigan, California, Chicago, New York and Washington, among other places.
On September 22, a balloon was seen flying near Donald Trump's [[Mar-a-Lago]] resort in West Palm Beach at a rally to mark the anniversary of [[Hurricane Maria]] striking Puerto Rico.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Andone |first1=Dakin |title='Baby Trump' balloon makes appearance at Florida rally |url=https://www.foxcarolina.com/news/us_and_world/baby-trump-balloon-makes-appearance-at-florida-rally/article_467ee804-4871-5abc-bba7-fe668ca2f038.html |website=FOX News |accessdate=November 12, 2018}}</ref>
On October 2, the balloon appeared at a Spokane, Washington protest when Vice President Mike Pence traveled to Washington to support the reelection of Representative [[Cathy McMorris Rodgers]].<ref name="HillBlog">{{cite web |last1=Ostalter |first1=Morgan |title=Trump 'baby blimp' flies over Chicago women’s rally ahead of midterms |url=https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/411268-trump-baby-blimp-flies-over-chicago-womens-rally |website=The Hill |accessdate=November 12, 2018}}</ref>
Baby Trump made an appearance at an October 13, Woman's March rally in Chicago, Illinois. The march was organized to encourage female political activism leading up to the November midterm elections.<ref name="HillBlog"/>
The balloon made its California debut at the Los Angeles Convention Center on October 19, 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-baby-trump-balloon-20181029-story.html|title='Baby Trump' balloon flies over downtown Los Angeles - Los Angeles Times|last=Martinez|first=Fidel|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-10-21}}</ref>
On October 27, the Trump balloon was flown in Grand Rapids, Michigan. The co-organizer stated, "It's meant to be fun, but we're also making the point that this guy is dangerous and he's a little unhinged. We want to make the point that this administration is taking us down what we think is the wrong path and is threatening to democracy, to our moral standing in the world."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kransz |first1=Michael |title=Huge 'Baby Trump' balloon to take flight in Grand Rapids |url=https://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2018/10/huge_baby_trump_blimp_to_take.html |website=Grand Rapids News |accessdate=November 12, 2018}}</ref>
On October 28, the Baby Trump balloon made an appearance in New York City at an "Impeachment parade."<ref>{{cite web |title=Baby Trump balloon makes appearance in New York at 'Impeachment parade' |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1tiaCkMekEA |website=YouTube |accessdate=November 12, 2018}}</ref>
===France===
The Baby Trump balloon made an appearance at a Paris protest march on November 11, 2018, when hundreds gathered to protest Trump's visit to Paris to attend the ceremonies to mark the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I. Speaking to a [[CNN]] journalist, one protester said, "I think Paris should be protesting not only Trump's presence here, but also should be trying to send a message to President Macron for having invited him here, especially on the anniversary of the signing of the armistice."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Keller |first1=Megan |title=‘Baby Trump’ balloon floats over Paris streets |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/news/416145-baby-trump-balloon-floats-over-paris-streets |website=The Hill |accessdate=November 12, 2018}}</ref>
===Argentina=== On November 29, 2018, the Trump Baby was flown in [[Argentina]] in protest during the [[2018 G20 Buenos Aires summit|G20 Buenos Aires summit]].<ref>{{cite news |title=G20 en Argentina: un "Trump bebé" en el Congreso inauguró las protestas contra la cumbre |trans-title=G20 in Argentina: A "Baby Trump" in Congress inaugurated the protests against the summit |url=https://tn.com.ar/sociedad/g20-en-argentina-un-trump-bebe-en-el-congreso-inauguro-las-protestas-contra-la-cumbre_920720 |work=TN |language=es |accessdate=30 November 2018 |date=29 November 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{YouTube|id=AlNU10Hkiu8|title=Trump Baby Balloon Steals Spotlight During London Protests}} (13 July 2018), [[CNBC]] * {{YouTube|id=10x49T4oAzY|title=Unedited/Raw video "Trump baby blimp flies in London – watch live", for a glance at the aeronautical performance.}} (13 July 2018), ''[[The Guardian]]''

revision.text:
'''''Droit de suite''''' ([[French language|French]] for "right to follow") is a right granted to [[artist]]s or their heirs, in some jurisdictions, to receive a fee on the resale of their works of art. This should be contrasted with policies such as the American [[first-sale doctrine]], where artists do not have the right to control or profit from subsequent sales. ==History== [[File:JEAN-FRANÇOIS MILLET - El Ángelus (Museo de Orsay, 1857-1859. Óleo sobre lienzo, 55.5 x 66 cm).jpg|thumb|''[[The Angelus (painting)|The Angelus]]'' was sold by Millet for 1,000 francs in 1865, but just 14 years after [[Jean-François Millet|Millet]]'s death in 1889 it was sold by the copper merchant [[Eugène Secrétan|Secrétan]] for 553,000 francs]] The ''droit de suite'' was first proposed in Europe around 1893, in response to a decrease in the importance of the salon, the end of the private patron, and to champion the cause of the “starving artist.”{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} Many artists, and their families, had suffered from the war, and ''droit de suite'' was a means to remedy socially difficult situations.[http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/12/cri/2005-2006/20060175.asp Assemblee-nationale.fr] {{fr icon}} According to [[Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres]], ''droit de suite'' was created in France following the sale of [[Jean-François Millet|Millet]]'s 1858 painting, the ''[[The Angelus (painting)|Angélus]]'', in 1889 at the [[Secretan sale]].{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} The owner of the painting made a huge profit from this sale, whereas the family of the artist lived in poverty. ==Legislation== ===European Union=== The [[Resale Rights Directive|2001/84/EC]] [[European Union directive|directive]] mandates a somewhat uniform system of ''droit de suite'' across the [[European Union]]. This directive is controversial in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2012/01/11/droit-de-suite-debate-heats-up/|title=‘Droit de Suite’ Debate Heats Up|first=Daniel|last=Grant|date=11 January 2012|publisher=}} ===France=== In [[France]], this system is in force through article L122-8 of the Code of intellectual property. It will be reformed by article 48 of the [[DADVSI]] law, which implements directive 2001/84/EC. During discussions in the French Parliament leading to this law, it was argued that in practice, the ''droit de suite'' is only paid at [[auction]]s, and that it thus disfavors the Paris art marketplace compared to [[London]] or [[New York City]]. Following DADVSI, a government regulation (through a [[decree]]) is to set degressive rates and maximal fees so that the Paris marketplace is not hindered.[http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/12/amendements/1206/120600232.asp Assemblee-nationale.fr] {{fr icon}} ===United States=== The [[California Resale Royalty Act]], (Civil Code section 986),{{cite web|url=http://law.onecle.com/california/civil/986.html|title=California Civil Code Section 986 - California Attorney Resources - California Laws|website=law.onecle.com}} was struck down as unconstitutional on May 17, 2012 because it violated the US Constitution Interstate Commerce clause, ending a 35-year run that entitled [[artist]]s to a [[royalty payment]] upon the [[resale]] of their works of art under certain circumstances. The ruling by Judge Jacqueline H. Nguyen of U.S. District Court Judge, Central District of California, is pending appeal in the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals. Judge Nguyen added:{{Cite web|url = http://www.artsjournal.com/culturegrrl/2012/05/court_calls_california_resale.html|title = BLOG: Federal Court Finds California Resale Royalties Act Unconstitutional|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}
The Court finds that the CRRA explicitly regulates applicable sales of fine art ''occurring wholly outside California'' [emphasis added]. Under its clear terms, the CRRA regulates transactions occurring anywhere in the United States, so long as the seller resides in California. Even the artist---the intended beneficiary of the CRRA---does not have to be a citizen of, or reside in, California....Therefore, the CRRA violates the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution.
California’s droit de suite statute, the California Resale Royalty Act, was enacted in 1976,{{cite web|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=1663016|title=The California Resale Royalty Act: Droit De [Not So] Suite|first=Emily|last=Barker|date=10 December 2009|publisher=|via=papers.ssrn.com}} and was struck down on May 17, 2012, pending appeal. The law applied to all works of fine art resold in California, or resold anywhere by a California resident, for a gross sale of $1000 or more. It had mandated a five percent royalty on the resale price of any work of fine art. An artist was able to waive this right “by a contract in writing providing for an amount in excess of five percent of the amount of such sale.” At least one scholar has proposed that this law is unconstitutional in that it effects a Fifth Amendment taking of private property. In September 2012, the [[U.S. Copyright Office]] published a "[[Notice of Inquiry]]" regarding establishing an artist "resale royalty right" in the US.[http://www.copyright.gov/docs/resaleroyalty/ "Resale Royalty Right"], U.S. Copyright Office (last visited October 24, 2012). The Notice was published in response to a request by Representative [[Jerrold Nadler]] and Senator [[Herb Kohl]], who had introduced droit de suite legislation in 2011.{{Cite book|title=Resale Royalties: An Updated Analysis|first=Maria|last=Pallante|publisher=Office of the Register of Copyrights|year=2013|url=http://www.copyright.gov/docs/resaleroyalty/usco-resaleroyalty.pdf|accessdate=2015-03-07|ref=harv|pages=3–5}} The Copyright Office's subsequent report endorsed "congressional consideration of a resale royalty right, or ''droit de suite'', which would give artists a percentage of the amount paid for a work each time it is resold by another party."{{sfn|Pallante|2013|p=10}} A follow-up bill was introduced in 2014, the American Royalties Too Act, and was vigorously opposed by auction houses.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/24/arts/design/auction-houses-taking-no-chances-on-american-royalties-too-act.html|date=2014-03-24|title=Lobbyists Set to Fight Royalty Bill for Artists|first=Patricia|last=Cohen|newspaper=New York Times}} The bill died in committee.{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/senate-bill/2045|work=Congress.gov|title=S.2045 - American Royalties Too Act of 2014|accessdate=2015-03-07}} ===Australia=== Australia The Resale Royalty Right for Visual Artists Act 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au|title=Australasian Legal Information Institute|website=www.austlii.edu.au}} gives the creator of an artwork the right to receive a royalty when their work is resold on the commercial art market. For artworks already in existence at 9 June 2010, the royalty applies only to the second and subsequent resales after that date. Under clauses 22 and 23 of the act artists have a case by case right to instruct the appointed government agency the Copyright Agency Ltd, to not collect and/or make their own individual collection arrangements. The royalty is calculated as 5% of the sale price, but does not apply where that price is less than $1,000. It is payable, via an official collecting agency,{{cite web|url=http://www.copyright.com.au|title=The Copyright Agency|website=Copyright Agency|accessdate=10 April 2012}} ''or'' if the creator chooses (on a case by case basis) it can be paid directly to the creator, on resales made during their lifetime and to their heirs for resales made up to 70 years after the creator’s death. The primary legal obligation to pay the royalty rests on the seller. However, in economic terms, it may effectively be passed on to the purchaser. Eligible artworks include original works of graphic or plastic art, including pictures, collages, paintings, drawings, engravings, prints, lithographs, sculptures, tapestries, ceramics, glassware, photographs, fine art textiles, installations, fine art jewellery, artists’ books, carvings and multi-media artworks. The royalty is restricted to Australian citizens or residents, though there is provision for reciprocal rights to be extended in the future to persons resident in other jurisdictions with compatible royalty schemes. The introduction of the scheme was controversial, as it has been elsewhere.{{cite web|url=http://www.artinsociety.com|title=Home|website=Journal of ART in SOCIETY|accessdate= 6 June 2013}} During the first three years of its operation, royalty payments totaling $1.5m were made to about 650 artists for 6,800 transactions, with about 50% going to Indigenous artists. The highest individual royalty was A$50,000. Most recipients have received amounts ranging from A$50 to A$500.{{cite web|url=http://www.resaleroyalty.org.au|title=Copyright Agency - Royalty Resale|website=www.resaleroyalty.org.au}} The average transaction cost is reportedly $30 AU.{{cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/qon/question?number=2677|title=Question on Notice|website=www.aph.gov.au}} A review of the scheme was announced in June 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.arts.gov.au/visual-arts/resale-royalty-scheme|title=Resale Royalty Scheme|first=Department of Communications and the|last=Arts|date=8 August 2016|website=www.arts.gov.au}} ===Philippines=== The Intellectual Property Code of the Philippines (Republic Act 8293) gives the author/artist or his heirs a 5-percent share in the gross proceeds of the sale or lease of the original painting, sculpture, or manuscript, subsequent to its first disposition by the creator. This right exists during the lifetime of the author or artist and fifty years after his/her death. ==See also== * [[California Resale Royalties Act]] * [[First-sale doctrine]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Droit De Suite}} [[Category:Copyright law]] [[Category:French law]] [[Category:Art and culture law]]

revision.comment: /* Critical response */ You're making an argument in Wikipedia's voice ("despite the fact..."). That argument needs attribution to an opinion in a secondary source (a magazine, book, review, etc.). Wikipedia cannot argue a point in its own voice. See [[wp:NPOV]], esp "Impartial tone".
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Everest | image = Everest poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Baltasar Kormákur]] | producer = {{Plainlist| *Baltasar Kormákur *[[Tim Bevan]] *[[Eric Fellner]] *Nicky Kentish Barnes *Tyler Thompson *[[Brian Oliver (producer)|Brian Oliver]] }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * [[William Nicholson (writer)|William Nicholson]] * [[Simon Beaufoy]] }} | based on = {{basedon|''Left For Dead: My Journey Home from Everest''|[[Beck Weathers]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| *[[Jason Clarke (actor)|Jason Clarke]] *[[Josh Brolin]] *[[John Hawkes (actor)|John Hawkes]] *[[Robin Wright]] *[[Emily Watson]] *[[Keira Knightley]] *[[Sam Worthington]] *[[Jake Gyllenhaal]] }} | music = [[Dario Marianelli]] | cinematography = [[Salvatore Totino]] | editing = [[Mick Audsley]] | studio = {{Plainlist| *[[Cross Creek Pictures]] *[[Walden Media]] *[[Working Title Films]] }} | distributor = [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2015|06|23|[[CineEurope]]|2015|09|18|United States}} | runtime = 121 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 121:14--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/everest-film | title=''EVEREST'' (12A) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=31 July 2015 | accessdate=31 July 2015}}</ref> | country = {{ubl|United Kingdom|United States}} | language = English | budget = $55 million<ref name="BOM"/> | gross = $203.4 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=everest2015.htm|title=Everest (2015)|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=([[Amazon.com]])|accessdate=29 January 2016}}</ref> }}
'''''Everest''''' is a 2015 [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[adventure film]] directed and produced by [[Baltasar Kormákur]] and written by [[William Nicholson (writer)|William Nicholson]] and [[Simon Beaufoy]], adapted from [[Beck Weathers]]' memoir ''Left for Dead: My Journey Home from Everest'' (2000). It stars an [[ensemble cast]] of [[Jason Clarke (actor)|Jason Clarke]], [[Josh Brolin]], [[John Hawkes (actor)|John Hawkes]], [[Robin Wright]], [[Michael Kelly (American actor)|Michael Kelly]], [[Sam Worthington]], [[Keira Knightley]], [[Emily Watson]], and [[Jake Gyllenhaal]]. It is based on the real events of the [[1996 Mount Everest disaster]], and focuses on the survival attempts of two expedition groups, one led by [[Rob Hall]] (Clarke) and the other by [[Scott Fischer]] (Gyllenhaal).
The film opened the [[72nd Venice International Film Festival]] on September 2, 2015, and was released theatrically on September 18, 2015.<ref name="release-date" /> It was first released in [[IMAX]] 3D on September 11, 2015, in the UK and in IMAX 3D, [[RealD 3D]], and 2D internationally, and exclusively in IMAX 3D, September 19, 2015 as a [[limited release]] in the United States and Canada, and along 36 other countries. It began a [[wide release]] in the United States on September 25, 2015. The film was a commercial success, grossing $203 million worldwide over a $55 million budget and received positive reviews from critics.
==Plot== <!-- Per WP:FILMPLOT, the plot summary should be 400-700 words. --> {{see also|1996 Mount Everest disaster}}
In May 1996, several commercial expeditions at base camp of [[Mount Everest]] prepare for a climb to the summit. [[Rob Hall]], who popularized commercial Everest missions, leads [[Adventure Consultants]]; [[Scott Fischer]] is chief guide for Rob's rival, [[Mountain Madness]]. Rob's clients include [[Beck Weathers]], an experienced climber; Doug Hansen, a former mailman pursuing his dream; climbing veteran [[Yasuko Namba]], who hopes to complete her final [[Seven Summits]] ascent; and [[Outside (magazine)|''Outside'']] magazine journalist [[Jon Krakauer]]. Helen Wilton manages Rob's base camp.
A month earlier in [[New Zealand]], Rob says goodbye to his pregnant wife Jan and promises that he will be home for the birth. At the base camp Rob receives a fax from her, informing him that their baby, not yet born, is a girl. He wants to name her Sarah, but Jan disagrees.
Worried about climber crowding, Rob persuades Scott to cooperate to reduce delays. On the summit attempt, Rob's group departs Camp IV before dawn, planning to complete the ascent and turn around by 2:00 P.M., the latest safe time for return before nightfall. The group is delayed over an hour after discovering that guide ropes are not installed on upper reaches of the climb. Beck has eyesight problems and stops. Rob tells him to return if his condition does not improve in a half-hour. Scott hurries back down to camp to help another climber, but plans to re-ascend. Rob warns him about overexertion.
Rob reaches the summit on time and is joined by other climbers including Yasuko, who jubilantly plants her Japanese flag in the snow. Descending, Rob encounters Doug struggling just above the [[Hillary Step]] and orders him to turn back. Doug insists on continuing, saying that he won't get the chance again. Rob reluctantly agrees and they reach the summit two hours later, well past safe return time. At the summit, Doug is exhausted and increasingly suffering from altitude sickness. Also at the top is Scott, exhausted and increasingly ill from [[high-altitude pulmonary edema]].
As Rob helps Doug descend, a blizzard strikes the mountain and Doug's oxygen tank is empty, causing him to suffer [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]]. No extra bottles are stored on the route where Rob asked and he radios Helen to send someone up with oxygen. Doug, left alone briefly by Rob, semi-consciously detaches himself from the guide rope and walks unsteadily along the narrow path. He silently topples to his death a moment later.
Scott's condition worsens. He tells his fellow climbers to continue descending without him. He lies down and later dies. Returning climbers reach Beck, whose vision is still impaired, but they all become lost as the blizzard obliterates the trail. Three climbers go for help, leaving Beck and Yasuko behind.
Guide Andy 'Harold' Harris reaches Rob with spare oxygen, but it is frozen shut. They huddle in place in the storm. While Rob sleeps, Andy begins to have hallucinations. He strips off his outer clothing and slides off the mountainside to his death. In the morning, Rob radios Helen that Doug and Andy are gone, and that his hands and feet are frozen. Helen calls Jan, hoping Rob will respond to her voice. Jan tells Rob that he must start moving. Rob tells her that he is cold but comfortable, and asks her to name their baby Sarah. He dies soon after.
Returning climbers tell the camp that Beck and Yasuko are stranded. The weather, however, makes rescue impossible. Helen calls Beck's wife, Peach, and informs her of the situation. In the morning, Beck miraculously awakens, witnesses Yasuko's corpse, and stumbles back to camp alone, severely frostbitten, and in desperate need of medical help. Peach calls the American Embassy and organizes a helicopter rescue. Nepal Army pilot Lt. Col. Madan Khatri Chhetri successfully flies a harrowing high altitude mission to evacuate Beck. Meanwhile, one of Scott's guides, Anatoli, finds his body, and moves it off the trail.
Returning home, Helen has an emotional reunion with Jan, who later gives birth and names her daughter Sarah. Beck returns to his family, heavily bandaged. Closing titles reveal that he lost both hands and nose to severe frostbite, and that Rob's body remains on Everest.
==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Jason Clarke (actor)|Jason Clarke]] as [[Rob Hall]], a New Zealand expedition group leader <ref name="four-cast" /> - Makes it to Summit but dies on way down - Wife has baby, Sarah *[[Jake Gyllenhaal]] as [[Scott Fischer]], an American expedition group leader <ref name="four-cast" /> He dies from altitude sickness, exhaustion and the storm on descent *[[Josh Brolin]] as [[Beck Weathers]], a U.S doctor <ref name="four-cast" /> and amateur mountain climber - Does not reach summit but lives with loss of two hands - Helicopter rescue. Wrote ''Left for Dead: my Journey Home from Everest'' in 2000 *[[Robin Wright]] as Peach Weathers, Beck's wife who remains in Texas <ref name="Sam-Robin" /> *[[John Hawkes (actor)|John Hawkes]] as Doug Hansen, a mailman<ref name="four-cast" /> and amateur mountain climber - Makes it to the summit on this second try but runs out of oxygen and falls to death *[[Sam Worthington]] as Guy Cotter,<ref name="Sam-Robin" /> a professional guide *[[Michael Kelly (American actor)|Michael Kelly]] as [[Jon Krakauer]], a journalist<ref name="four-cast-wrap" /> and amateur mountain climber. Survived and wrote ''[[Into Thin Air]]'' (1997) which was basis for a TV movie *[[Keira Knightley]] as Jan Arnold, Rob Hall's pregnant wife<ref name="Keira" /> who remains home in New Zealand - Gives birth to Sarah after Rob's death *[[Emily Watson]] as Helen Wilton,<ref name="four-cast-wrap" /> the base camp manager *[[Tom Wright (Australian actor)|Thomas Wright]] as [[Michael Groom (climber)|Michael Groom]], an Australian mountain climber <ref name="four-cast-wrap" /> - Survivor guide on Hall team, Adventure Consultants *[[Martin Henderson]] as [[Andy Harris (mountain guide)|Andy "Harold" Harris]],<ref name="four-cast-wrap" /> a professional guide - Andy gets rescue Oxygen to Rob but dies overnight in storm *[[Elizabeth Debicki]] as Dr. Caroline Mackenzie, the base camp physician *[[Naoko Mori]] as [[Yasuko Namba]], an experienced amateur mountain climber - Reaches the summit, her seventh, but dies on descent *[[Clive Standen]] as [[Ed Viesturs]]<ref name="Clive" /> *[[Vanessa Kirby]] as [[Sandy Hill (mountaineer)|Sandy Hill]] *[[Tom Goodman-Hill]] as [[Neal Beidleman]] - Reached summit and survivor as guide on Fischer's team, Mountain Madness *[[Ingvar Eggert Sigurðsson]] as [[Anatoli Boukreev]] - A guide with Scott's team who survived and wrote ''[[The Climb (book)|The Climb: Tragic Ambitions on Everest]]'' (1997) *Charlotte Bøving as [[Lene Gammelgaard]], a successful Danish climber in Fischer's group - Survivor who wrote, ''Climbing High: A Woman's Account of Surviving the Everest Tragedy'' (2000) *[[Micah Hauptman]] as [[David Breashears]], a documentary filmmaker and mountaineer <ref name="Micah" /> *[[Chris Reilly]] as Klev Schoening - Turned back and a survivor of Fischer's team *Chike Chan as [[Gau Ming-Ho|Makalu Gau]] - Leader of Taiwanese expedition *Vijay Lama as Lt. Col. Madan Khatri Chhetri, Nepal Army helicopter pilot - Rescues Beck Weathers *[[Mark Derwin]] as [[After the Wind|Lou Kasischke]] -Turns back and is a Hall team survivor who writes book ''[[After the Wind|After the Wind: 1996 Everest Tragedy: One Survivor's Story]]'' (2014) *[[Mia Goth]] as Meg, Weathers' daughter {{div col end}}
==Production==
===Development=== [[Baltasar Kormákur]] directed the film, about the [[1996 Mount Everest disaster|1996 disastrous expedition]] to scale [[Mount Everest]], which was scripted by [[Simon Beaufoy]] and [[Mark Medoff]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/everest-release-date-pushed-back-690289 | title='Everest' Release Date Pushed Back Seven Months | work=The Hollywood Reporter | date=21 March 2014 | accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> with early script adaptations carried out by Justin Isbell and [[William Nicholson (writer)|William Nicholson]]. The film was produced by [[Working Title Films]].<ref name=Baltasar>{{cite news|last=Hopewell|first=John|title='2 Guns' Helmer Kormakur Set to Climb 'Everest'|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/international/2-guns-kormakur-set-to-climb-everest-1200574821/|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=variety.com|date=6 August 2013}}</ref> [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] distributes the film in the United States.<ref name="Christian" /> The film was produced by [[Tim Bevan]] and [[Eric Fellner]], and started shooting in November 2013.<ref name="four" /> In September 2013, [[Emmett/Furla/Oasis Films]] were set to co-finance the film,<ref>{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Corsan NV Invests $125 Million in Emmett/Furla/Oasis Slate|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/09/toronto-corsan-nv-invests-125-million-in-emmettfurlaoasis-slate/|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=10 September 2013}}</ref> but in October they exited as co-financiers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Universal, Baltasar Kormakur Lose Co-Fi But Still Plan November Climb|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/10/everest-update-sony-eyes-march-for-doug-limans-pic-universal-baltasar-kormakur-lose-co-fi-but-still-plan-november-climb/|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=21 October 2013}}</ref>
After the production start date of 6 November 2013 had passed,<ref>{{cite news|last=Siegel|first=Tatiana|title='Everest' Movie Rescued by Cross Creek Pictures|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/everest-movie-rescued-by-cross-655467|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=hollywoodreporter.com|date=12 November 2013}}</ref> [[Cross Creek Pictures]] and [[Walden Media]] joined the production on 12 November 2013, and financed the film with $65 million.<ref name=cross>{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Working Title's 'Everest' Is Real: Cross Creek And Walden Media To Co-Finance Pic|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/11/working-titles-everest-is-real-cross-creek-and-walden-media-to-co-finance-pic/|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=12 November 2013}}</ref> The film started production on 13 January 2014, in the [[Ötztal Alps]] in [[Italy]], after which production moved to [[Nepal]] and [[Iceland]].<ref name="cross" /><ref name=Jan13>{{cite news|last=McNary|first=Dave|title='Everest' Set to Start Shooting in Italy on Jan. 13|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/everest-set-to-start-shooting-in-italy-on-jan-13-1200824835/|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=variety.com|date=12 November 2013}}</ref> On 11 December 2013, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' posted that [[South Tyrol]]'s regional film board added $1 million to the film's funding.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roxborough|first=Scott|title=Jake Gyllenhaal-Starrer 'Everest' Gets $1 Million in Funding From South Tirol|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jake-gyllenhaal-starrer-everest-gets-664929|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=hollywoodreporter.com|date=11 December 2013}}</ref>
On 30 January 2014, Universal set a 27 February 2015 release date for the film,<ref>{{cite news|title=Universal Sets Dates For 'Everest', Guillermo Del Toro's 'Crimson Peak', Others|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/01/universal-sets-dates-for-everest-guillermo-del-toros-crimson-peak-others/|accessdate=31 January 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=30 January 2014}}</ref> but on 21 March 2014, it was moved to 18 September 2015.<ref name=release-date>{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=Universal Moves 'Everest' to September 2015|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/universal-moves-everest-to-september-2015-1201141919/|accessdate=22 March 2014|newspaper=variety.com|date=21 March 2014}}</ref>
===Pre-production=== As of 19 February 2013, [[Christian Bale]] was in talks to join the cast of the disaster film to play [[Rob Hall]], the leader of a New Zealand group who ran [[Adventure Consultants]].<ref name=Christian>{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|title=Christian Bale in Talks to Star in 'Everest'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/christian-bale-talks-star-everest-422327|accessdate=16 January 2014|newspaper=hollywoodreporter.com|date=19 February 2013}}</ref> On 17 July, [[Jake Gyllenhaal]], [[Josh Brolin]], [[Jason Clarke (actor)|Jason Clarke]] and [[John Hawkes (actor)|John Hawkes]] were cast as leads in the film. Bale dropped out around this time.<ref name=four>{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Josh Brolin, John Hawkes, Jake Gyllenhaal & Jason Clarke in Talks To Star In 'Everest' For Working Title|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/everest-movie-casting-brolin-hawkes-gyllenhaal-clarke/|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=17 July 2013}}</ref> Gyllenhaal played [[Scott Fischer]], the leader of the [[Mountain Madness]] expedition; Brolin played [[Beck Weathers]], a doctor; Clarke took the role of Rob Hall, also an expedition leader; and Hawkes played Doug Hansen, one of Rob Hall's clients, who encounters difficulties on the descent from the summit of Everest.<ref name=four-cast>{{cite news|title=Universal in Talks for 'Everest' With Josh Brolin and Jake Gyllenhaal|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/universal-talks-everest-josh-brolin-584000|accessdate=17 January 2014|newspaper=hollywoodreporter.com|date=17 July 2013}}</ref>
On 4 February 2014, [[Clive Standen]] also joined the cast, while shooting was underway.<ref name=Clive>{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title='Vikings' Actor Clive Standen Joins Working Title's 'Everest'|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/vikings-clive-standen-working-titles-everest-1201086429/|accessdate=5 February 2014|newspaper=variety.com|date=4 February 2014}}</ref> On 7 February 2014, more cast was added to the film, including [[Martin Henderson]], [[Emily Watson]], [[Tom Wright (Australian actor)|Thomas M. Wright]], and [[Michael Kelly (American actor)|Michael Kelly]]. Watson played a motherly base camp figure who works closely with Rob Hall, and Kelly played ''[[Into Thin Air]]'' author [[Jon Krakauer]].<ref name=four-cast-wrap>{{cite news|last=Sneider|first=Jeff|title=Martin Henderson, Emily Watson, Thomas Wright Climb Aboard 'Everest'|url=http://www.thewrap.com/martin-henderson-emily-watson-thomas-wright-climb-aboard-everest-exclusive/|accessdate=9 February 2014|newspaper=thewrap.com|date=7 February 2014}}</ref> On 17 February, actor [[Micah Hauptman]] was added to the cast in the role of filmmaker and mountaineer [[David Breashears]], who directed the 1998 [[IMAX]] documentary film ''[[Everest (1998 film)|Everest]]''.<ref name=Micah>{{cite news|title=Micah Hauptman Scales 'Everest'|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/02/micah-hauptman-scales-everest-charles-s-dutton-boards-gregg-allman-biopic-midnight-rider/#more-683558|accessdate=18 February 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=17 February 2014}}</ref> On 24 March 2014, [[Sam Worthington]] and [[Robin Wright]] joined the cast. Worthington played Guy Cotter and Wright played Beck Weathers' wife, Peach.<ref name=Sam-Robin>{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Sam Worthington, Robin Wright Join Universal's 'Everest' Expedition|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/03/sam-worthington-robin-wright-join-universals-everest-expedition/|accessdate=24 March 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=24 March 2014}}</ref> On 1 May, [[DailyMail.co.uk]] revealed that [[Keira Knightley]] had joined the film as Jan Arnold, Rob Hall's pregnant wife.<ref name=Keira>{{cite news|last=BAMIGBOYE|first=BAZ|title=Wolf whistles for the racy Tudors|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2618290/BAZ-BAMIGBOYE-Wolf-whistles-racy-Tudors.html|accessdate=8 May 2014|newspaper=dailymail.co.uk|date=1 May 2014}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[File:Blick von Kreuzspitze ins Schnalstal.jpg|thumb|right|Additional portions of the film, including scenes that take place just above the icefall to camp 3, were filmed at 10,000 feet at [[Schnalstal|Schnalstal/Val Senales]] in [[South Tyrol]], Italy.<ref name="cinema"/>]]
In November 2013, the film was set for a 13 January 2014 production start date in Italy. Co-financier Brian Oliver told ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' they would shoot in [[Ötztal Alps]] in Italy for six weeks, a month in Iceland, and then move to Nepal for another month's shoot.<ref name="Jan13" /> In early January 2014, actors Gyllenhaal and Brolin were practicing for climbing mountains in the [[Santa Monica Mountains]], to train for their roles.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jake Gyllenhaal, Josh Brolin reportedly get lost hiking|url=http://www.azcentral.com/thingstodo/celebrities/free/20140110jake-gyllenhall-josh-brolin-hiking-disaster.html|accessdate=16 January 2014|newspaper=azcentral.com|date=10 January 2014}}</ref>
The 44-member crew arrived on 12 January 2014 in [[Nepal]] and stayed in [[Kathmandu]]. They had permission to film from 9 to 23 January.<ref name=TIA>{{cite news|title=TIA domestic terminal turns into Hollywood set for 'Everest'|url=http://www.myrepublica.com/portal/index.php?action=news_details&news_id=67980|accessdate=16 January 2014|newspaper=myrepublica.com|date=15 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=France-Presse|first=Agence|title=Actors Jake Gyllenhaal and Josh Brolin in Nepal to shoot Everest film 'Into Thin Air'|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2014/01/13/actors-jake-gyllenhaal-and-josh-brolin-in-nepal-to-shoot-everest-film-into-thin-air/|accessdate=16 January 2014|newspaper=rawstory.com|date=13 January 2014}}</ref> Later filming on ''Everest'' commenced on 13 January 2014.<ref name=filming>{{cite news|last=Daniels|first=Nia|title=Working Title starts on Everest film|url=http://www.theknowledgeonline.com/the-knowledge-bulletin/post/2014/01/14/Working-Title-starts-on-Everest-film|accessdate=15 January 2014|newspaper=theknowledgeonline.com|date=14 January 2014}}</ref> On 14 January, Brolin and Hawkes filmed shots<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toolazyforyoga.blogspot.com/2014/01/hollywood-comes-to-kathmandu-and-i-get.html|title=Notes from Nepal: Diary of a Himalayan Housewife|author=Monsoon Rose|publisher=}}</ref> at local terminal of [[Tribhuvan International Airport]], and then they were to be filming at [[Tenzing-Hillary Airport|Lukla Airport]] on 15 January, then to [[Namche Bazaar]], and later at the [[Everest Base Camp]], news confirmed.<ref name="TIA" /> After shooting completed in Nepal, the crews were to move to [[Italy]] ([[Schnalstal]] and [[Rome]]),<ref>{{cite news|title=Kormakur's 'Everest' to open Venice Film Festival|url=http://www.agi.it/en/italy/news/kormakur_s_everest_to_open_venice_film_festival-201507082052-epp-rt10181|accessdate=31 July 2015|newspaper=agi.it|date=8 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926133858/https://www.agi.it/en/italy/news/kormakur_s_everest_to_open_venice_film_festival-201507082052-epp-rt10181|archivedate=26 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and then in early March to the [[United Kingdom]], to film at [[Pinewood Studios]].<ref name="filming" /> On 23 February 2014, Gyllenhaal was spotted in [[Rome]] during filming, which recently wrapped up in Nepal.<ref>{{cite news|last=White|first=Chelsea|title=When in Rome! Bearded Jake Gyllenhaal given tour of Italian sights by mystery woman as he starts shooting Everest film|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2567600/A-hairy-Jake-Gyllenhaal-shown-Italian-sights-mystery-woman-starts-filming-tragic-Everest-tale.html|accessdate=26 February 2014|newspaper=dailymail.co.uk|date=25 February 2014}}</ref> Brolin was also spotted with his assistant, Kathryn Boyd.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mixing business with pleasure! Josh Brolin and his assistant turned love interest Kathryn Boyd kiss in Rome|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2567108/Josh-Brolin-assistant-Kathryn-Boyd-public-romance-kiss-Rome.html|accessdate=26 February 2014|newspaper=dailymail.co.uk|date=25 February 2014}}</ref>
English actor [[Clive Standen]] has said that filming on location in freezing temperatures has been "tough but fun".<ref>{{cite news|title=Standen: Filming Everest is tough|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/movies/standen-filming-everest-is-tough-30049493.html|accessdate=1 March 2014|newspaper=independent.ie|date=28 February 2014}}</ref> On 24 March 2014 the shooting was said to be taking place at the [[Everest Base Camp]] in Nepal.<ref name="Sam-Robin" /> Base camp exteriors were filmed on the backlot at [[Cinecitta Studios]] in Rome, where bright sunlight could be achieved to resemble the lighting at base camp.<ref name="cinema"/>
On 18 April 2014, while the second unit crew was shooting remaining scenes of the film at Camp II on Everest, [[2014 Mount Everest avalanche|an avalanche]] struck, killing 16 [[Sherpa people|Sherpa]] guides. The Sherpas were carrying equipment and supplies to camps for climbers in advance of the start of the summer climbing season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Everest avalanche kills at least 12 Sherpa guides|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-27075638|accessdate=19 April 2014|newspaper=bbc.com|date=18 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mount Everest avalanche sweeps away Nepalese guides|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/18/mount-everest-avalanche-climbers|accessdate=19 April 2014|newspaper=theguardian.com|date=18 April 2014}}</ref> ''[[Deadline Hollywood|Deadline]]'' reported there were no injuries or fatalities affecting the film crew. The production was not present where the disaster took place, but they were nearby. Filming at [[Pinewood Studios]] in England was just about to finish up, but the second unit was shooting at the camp which then had to halt the production for some time.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title='Everest' Movie Crew OK After Tragic Avalanche|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/04/everest-movie-crew-okay-after-tragic-avalanche/|accessdate=19 April 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=18 April 2014}}</ref> [[Hillary Step]], camp 4, icefall and the summit were built on the 007 stage at Pinewood Studios with greenscreen for CG backgrounds. Totino said, "It was very challenging because we had to re-create the sun, which at Everest is so incredibly sharp and crisp." The team used SoftSun lights for creating sun on the summit, Hillary Step and icefall. "They were 9 feet long and 3 ½ feet in diameter and 100,000 watts. They had to be moved around on cranes because they are very heavy," Totino said.<ref name="cinema"/> To photograph one scene during which expedition guide Rob Hall (Jason Clarke) is stuck on the mountain in the storm, Totino recalled: "We tented off a portion of the set with some very heavy plastic and brought in these giant refrigerating units, half the size of a semi truck, and we cooled that part of the stage down to about 26 to 28 degrees Fahrenheit [around -3°C] and brought in real snow. Baltasar really wanted the actor to feel like he was frozen. You really see and feel that."<ref name="cinema"/> The film was shot with [[Arri Alexa XT]] cameras, using the Arriraw format.<ref name="cinema">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/everest-cinematographer-recalls-very-difficult-818689|title='Everest' Cinematographer Recalls "Very Difficult Shoot"|first=Carolyn | last=Giardina|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=18 September 2015|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref>
===Music=== [[Dario Marianelli]] composed the music for the film.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dario Marianelli to Score 'Everest'|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/07/02/dario-marianelli-to-score-everest/|accessdate=13 July 2014|publisher=filmmusicreporter.com|date=2 July 2014}}</ref> The film uses the song "Yeh ladka hai Allah"<ref name="Yeh Ladka Hai Allah">{{cite web|title=Yeh Ladka Hai Allah|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BE8_rNJOQ-0|website=YouTube|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref> from the Bollywood film ''[[Kabhi Khushi Kabhie Gham]]'' (2001), when the climbing party first arrives in Nepal. The song plays in the bus when it passes through a busy Nepali bazaar. Another song in the film is "[[All I Wanna Do (Sheryl Crow song)|All I Wanna Do]]", performed by [[Sheryl Crow]], which is accurate to the timing of the film's events, in 1996. The song "[[Weather with You]]" by [[Crowded House]] also features in the film. The soundtrack was released on 18 September 2015 by [[Varèse Sarabande]].
==Release== Universal Pictures had originally slated the film for a 27 February 2015 release date in the United States and Canada.<ref name="release-date" /> However, the film was released on 18 September 2015 exclusively in [[IMAX 3D]], followed by a wide theatrical release on 25 September 2015.<ref name="IMAXr">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/everest-shifts-release-get-run-804290|title='Everest' Shifts Release to Get Exclusive Run in Imax, Large-Format Theaters|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=22 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> In the United States and Canada, it was released in [[Dolby Laboratories|Dolby Vision]] format in [[Dolby Cinema]], the first ever for Universal Pictures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/hunger-games-pixels-everest-coming-810024|title='Hunger Games,' 'Pixels,' 'Everest' Among Upcoming Dolby Cinema Titles|first=Carolyn | last=Giardina|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=22 July 2015|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref> It was screened at the 2015 [[CineEurope]] on 23 June 2015 at the [[List of convention and exhibition centers|Centre Convencions Internacional Barcelona]] in full [[3D film|3D]] [[Dolby Atmos]].<ref name="premiere">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/all-star-disaster-epic-everest-801215|title=All-Star Disaster Epic 'Everest' Screening at CineEurope|first=Alex | last=Ritman|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=9 June 2015|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cineeurope-universal-serves-up-crimson-804437|title=CineEurope: Universal Serves Up 'Crimson Peak,' 'Steve Jobs,' 'The Danish Girl' Footage|first=Alex | last=Ritman|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=23 June 2015|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref> The film's world premiere took place on 2 September 2015 at the [[72nd Venice International Film Festival]] in the Sala Grande, at the city's Palazzo del Cinema in [[Venice]].<ref name="releases">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/everest-open-venice-film-festival-807288|title=All-Star Disaster Epic 'Everest' to Open Venice Film Festival|author=Georg Szalai|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=8 July 2015|accessdate=8 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/08/everest-imax-trailer-jason-clarke-jake-gyllenhaal-baltasar-kormakur-universal-1201492991/|title='Everest' Imax Trailer: Chilling New Peek At Epic Mountain Climbing Drama|first=Nancy | last=Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
===Marketing=== On 12 February 2014, the first photo from the set of the film was revealed, featuring Clarke.<ref>{{cite news|last=Anderton|first=Ethan|title=First Look: Jason Clarke Faces the Cold in Baltasar Kormákur's 'Everest'|url=http://www.firstshowing.net/2014/first-look-jason-clarke-faces-the-cold-in-baltasar-kormakurs-everest/|accessdate=13 February 2014|newspaper=firstshowing.net|date=12 February 2014}}</ref> On 4 June 2015, the first trailer for the film was released online, with an appeal for relief for the [[April 2015 Nepal earthquake]] through [[Oxfam America]] in the [[Post-credits scene|coda]].
===Home media=== DVD, Blu-ray and Blu-ray 3D versions were released on 19 January 2016. On 27 September 2016, Universal Studios Home Entertainment released a 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray Disc edition of the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hd-report.com/2016/09/29/this-weeks-new-4k-ultra-hd-blu-ray-releases-with-hdr/|title=New Ultra HD Blu-ray Releases With HDR|work=HD Report|date=28 September 2016|accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''Everest'' grossed $43.4 million in North America and $159.9 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $203.4 million, against a budget of $55 million.<ref name=BOM /> ''Everest'' had the biggest September worldwide IMAX opening with $7.2 million, breaking the record previously held by ''[[Resident Evil: Retribution]]'' ($6 million).<ref name="Overseas8thOpening"/>
Prior to its wide theatrical opening in the United States and Canada on 25 September, the film received a limited release in IMAX 3D and other premium large format screens across 545 theaters on 18 September in order to build good [[word of mouth]].<ref name="IMAXr"/> It made $325,000 from 481 IMAX screens and premium large-format screens from late night showings, which began at 7 pm,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/maze-runner-the-scorch-trials-black-mass-everest-captive-box-office-1201533896/|title='Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials’, ‘Black Mass’, ‘Everest’ Start Their Weekend Climb With Thursday Previews – Update|author=Anthony D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=18 September 2015|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-maze-runner-sequel-824533|title=Box Office: 'Maze Runner' Sequel Opens to $1.7M Thursday Night; 'Black Mass' Nabs $1.4M|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=18 September 2015|accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref> and an estimated $2.3 million on its opening day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/maze-runner-the-scorch-trials-black-mass-everest-captive-box-office-1201533896/|title='Scorch Trials' Runs Behind 'Maze Runner'; 'Black Mass' Bests 'B’ Exit Poll – Saturday AM B.O. Update|author=Anthony D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=19 September 2015|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref> It finished off the weekend at number five with $7.6 million from 368 IMAX and 177 premium large-format theaters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-maze-runner-sequel-825029|title=Box Office: 'Maze Runner' Sequel No. 1 With $30.3M; 'Black Mass' Scores $23.4M|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=20 September 2015|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="imax"/> IMAX comprised 78% ($5.8 million) of the opening weekend gross while premium large formats contributed 22% ($1.7 million).<ref name="imax">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2015/09/20/box-office-everest-scores-7-5m-in-imaxplf-emily-blunts-sicario-kicks-butt-on-6-screens/|title=Box Office: 'Everest' Scores $7.5M In IMAX, Emily Blunt's 'Sicario' Kicks Butt On 6 Screens|author=Scott Mendelson|work=[[Forbes]]|date=20 September 2015|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref> This broke the record for the biggest IMAX September debut (breaking ''[[The Equalizer (film)|The Equalizer]]''{{'}}s $3.1 million record in 2014).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=4107&p=.htm|title='Maze' and 'Mass' Top Box Office, but 'Everest' and 'Sicario' are the Story|author=Brad Brevet|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=([[Amazon.com]])|date=20 September 2015|accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref> ''Everest'' is the first major film since ''[[Mission: Impossible – Ghost Protocol]]'' (2011) to receive IMAX only release for more than two days (''[[The Walk (2015 film)|The Walk]]'' became the next when it replaced ''Everest'' on 30 September 2015).<ref name="imax"/>
''Everest'' expanded into a total of 3,006 theaters on Friday after a limited 3D, IMAX and other premium large formats engagement. It earned $4 million on its wide opening day on Friday.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2015/09/26/box-office-johnny-depps-black-mass-drops-60-everest-and-sicario-successfully-expand/|title=Box Office: Johnny Depp's 'Black Mass' Drops 60%, 'Everest' And 'Sicario' Successfully Expand|author=Scott Mendelson|work=[[Forbes]]|date=26 September 2015|accessdate=26 September 2015}}</ref> During its wide opening weekend it earned $13.09 million from 3,006 theaters of which $3.7 million came from 366 IMAX screens raising its total North America IMAX revenue to $11.5 million—the first ever September IMAX release to reach past $10 million.<ref name="Demo">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/the-intern-hotel-transylvania-2-the-green-inferno-weekend-box-office-1201550112/|title=Sony's Luxury 'Hotel Transylvania 2' Setting Records; 'The Intern' Eyes $18.2M Weekend Salary – Sunday AM First Update|author=Anthony D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=27 September 2015|accessdate=27 September 2015}}</ref> The largest demographic of the opening weekend audience was male (51%) and under the age of 35 (45%).<ref name="Demo"/>
Internationally, ''Everest'' was released in a total of 65 countries.<ref name="Everest2">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/everest-univerisal-overseas-box-office-opening-1201536493/|title=Overseas Moviegoers Begin Hiking To 'Everest' In 36 Territories|first1=Anthony | last1=D'Alessandro | first2=Nancy | last2=Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=19 September 2015|accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> In its opening weekend, it grossed $28.8 million from 5,154 screens from 36 markets opening at No. 1 in 12 countries.<ref name="Overseas8thOpening">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/maze-runner-scorch-trials-everest-minions-mission-impossible-rogue-nation-pixels-universal-record-international-box-office-1201538355/|title='Scorch Trials' Heats Up $43.2M; 'Everest' Scales $28.8M – Intl Box Office Final|first=Nancy | last=Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=21 September 2015|accessdate=22 September 2015}}</ref> IMAX comprised $3 million of the opening gross.<ref name="Overseas8thOpening"/> In its second weekend, it expanded to 22 more markets earning $33.9 million from 62 markets—topping the box office.<ref name="Overseas9thOpening">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/hotel-transylvania-2-the-intern-pan-sicario-lost-in-hong-kong-box-office-international-1201553347/|title='Hotel Transylvania 2,' ‘The Intern' Bow Amidst Holdovers 'Everest' And 'Scorch Trials' – Intl Box Office Update|author=Anita Busch|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=28 September 2015|accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> Russia and the CIS posted the highest opening with $5.2 million followed by the United Kingdom, Ireland and Malta ($4.9 million), Mexico ($4.4 million), Germany ($2.9 million) and Australia ($2.4 million).<ref name="Overseas8thOpening"/><ref name="Overseas9thOpening"/> In terms of total earnings, the United Kingdom ($16 million) and Germany ($9.3 million) are the largest markets. It became the 8th Universal Pictures film of 2015 to cross the £10 million mark in the United Kingdom. The only other studios ever to achieve the feat are [[20th Century Fox]] in 2014 and [[Paramount Pictures]] in 2011.<ref name="Overseas12thOpening">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/crimson-peak-ant-man-martian-hotel-transylvania-scorch-trials-pan-international-box-office-results-1201586990/|title='Ant-Man' Supersizes With $43.2M China Bow; 'Crimson Peak' Reaps $13.4M – International Box Office|first=Nancy | last=Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=18 October 2015|accessdate=19 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="Overseas13thOpening">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/paranormal-activity-ghost-dimension-witch-hunter-martian-ant-man-hotel-transylvania-international-box-office-results-1201592886/|title='The Martian' Crosses $200M; 'Ghost Dimension' Sets Series Records; 'Ant-Man' Leggy in China – Intl B.O. Update|first=Nancy | last=Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=25 October 2015|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> It opened in China on 3 November and Japan on 6 November<ref name="Overseas12thOpening"/> and grossed $11.3 million and $1.4 million respectively debuting both at No. 4 at the box office.<ref name="Overseas14thOpening">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/11/spectre-sony-hotel-transylvania-2-martian-last-witch-hunter-scouts-guide-zombie-apocalypse-international-box-office-results-1201602038/|title=Sony's Sizzling 'Spectre', 'Hotel Transylvania 2' Top Charts in Strong Frame – Intl Box Office Update|first=Nancy | last=Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=2 November 2015|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> In China notably, despite having the advantage of securing all the IMAX screens, it had to face serious competition with Hollywood counterparts such as ''[[Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials]]'', ''[[The Peanuts Movie]]'' and four new local movies that all opened that same week.<ref name="Overseas14thOpening"/> It has so far grossed a total of $16 million in China and $5.1 million in Japan.<ref name="Overseas16thOpening">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/11/hunger-games-mockingjay-part-2-spectre-international-box-office-results-1201634041/|title='Mockingjay' Lands At $144.5M As China & Caution in Europe Squeeze Hwd – Intl B.O. Final|first=Nancy | last=Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=24 November 2015|accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref>
===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds a rating of 73%, based on 220 reviews, with an average rating of 6.7/10. The site's consensus reads, "''Everest'' boasts all the dizzying cinematography a person could hope to get out a movie about mountain climbers, even if it's content to tread less challenging narrative terrain."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/everest_2015/ |title=Everest |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Flixster]] |accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]] the film has a score of 64 out of 100, based on 39 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/everest |title=Everest |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref>
[[Jon Krakauer]], author of ''[[Into Thin Air]]'', denounced the movie, stating some of its details were fabricated and defamatory. He also expressed regret regarding Sony's rapid acquisition of the rights to the book. Director [[Baltasar Kormákur]] responded, claiming Krakauer's first-person account was not used as source material for the film and alleging that Krakauer's version conflicted with actual events.<ref name=krakauerNotFan>{{cite news|last1=McGovern|first1=Joe|title=Into Thin Air author Jon Krakauer is not a fan of Everest|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/09/25/thin-air-author-jon-krakauer-not-fan-everest|accessdate=23 November 2015|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=25 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="Into Thin Air">{{cite book |last1=Krakauer |first1=Jon |title=Into Thin Air |date=1997 |publisher=Villard Books |location=United States |isbn=978-0385494786 |page=300ff |pages=416 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gt7EQgH8-b4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=into+thin+air&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGo63LnPXeAhWE61MKHRlOBy4Q6AEIKjAA#v=onepage&q=into%20thin%20air&f=false |accessdate=27 November 2018 |ref=Into Thin Air}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Award ! Category ! Nominee(s) ! Result |- | [[Camerimage]] | Best 3D Film | [[Salvatore Totino]] | {{nom}} |- | [[22nd Screen Actors Guild Awards|Screen Actors Guild Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sagawards.org/awards/nominees-and-recipients/22nd-annual-screen-actors-guild-awards|title=The 22nd Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards|publisher=}}</ref> | [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Stunt Ensemble in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Performance by a Stunt Ensemble in a Motion Picture]] ! | {{nom}} |- | [[20th Satellite Awards|Satellite Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/2015-satellite-award-nominees-announced-844739|title=2015 Satellite Award Nominees announced|author=Gregg Kilday|date=1 December 2015|work=The Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> | [[Satellite Award for Best Visual Effects|Best Effects]] ! | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2" | [[Visual Effects Society Awards 2015|Visual Effects Society]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/in-contention/star-wars-the-force-awakens-game-of-thrones-peanuts-movie-visual-effects-society-award-nominations-1201677466/|title='Star Wars,' ‘Game of Thrones' lead Visual Effects Society nominations - Variety|author=Margaret Lenker|work=Variety}}</ref> | Outstanding Supporting Visual Effects in a Photoreal Feature | Dadi Einarsson, Roma O-Connor, Matthias Bjarnsasson, Richard Van Den Bergh | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Models in a Photoreal or Animated Project ("Mt. Everest") | Matthias Bjarnasson, Olafur Haraldsson, Kjartan Hardarson, Peter Arnorsson | {{nom}} |- | [[42nd Saturn Awards|Saturn Awards]]<ref name="Saturn 42">{{cite web|url=http://www.saturnawards.org/The-Saturn-Awards-Annual-Nominations.php |title=The 2015 Nominees |publisher=[[Saturn Award]]s |date= |accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref> | [[Saturn Award for Best Action or Adventure Film|Best Action or Adventure Film]] ! | {{nom}} |}
